verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:1
verses.text: Book II.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:2
verses.text: Jerome answers the second, third, and fourth propositions of Jovinianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:6
verses.text: That those who have become regenerate cannot be overthrown by the devil, Jerome (c.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:7
verses.text: 1) puts it that they cannot be tempted by the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:8
verses.text: He quotes 1 John i.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:9
verses.text: 8–ii.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:10
verses.text: 2, as shewing that faithful men can be tempted and sin and need an advocate.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:11
verses.text: The expressions (3) in Heb.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:12
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:13
verses.text: as to those who crucify the Son of God afresh do not apply to ordinary sins after baptism, as supposed by Montanus and Novatus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:14
verses.text: The epistles to the Seven Churches show that the lapsed may return.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:15
verses.text: The Angels, and even our Lord Himself, (4) could be tempted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:16
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:19
verses.text: That there is no difference (morally) between one who fasts and one who takes food with thanksgiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:20
verses.text: Jovinian has quoted (5) many texts of Scripture to show that God has made animals for men's food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:21
verses.text: But (6) there are many other uses of animals besides food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:22
verses.text: And there are many warnings like 1 Cor.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:23
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:24
verses.text: 13, as to the danger arising from food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:25
verses.text: There are among the heathen (7) many instances of abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:26
verses.text: They recognize (8) the evil of sensual allurements, and often, like Crates the Theban, (9) have cast away what would tempt them; the senses, they teach, (10) should be subject to reason; and, that (11) except for athletes (Christians do not want to be like Milo of Crotona) bread and water suffice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:27
verses.text: Horace (12), Xenophon and other eminent Greeks (13), the Essenes and the Brahmans (14), as well as philosophers like Diogenes, testify to the value of abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:28
verses.text: The Old Testament stories (15) of Esau's pottage, of the lusting of Israel for the flesh-pots of Egypt, and those in the New Testament of Anna, Cornelius, &c.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:29
verses.text: , commend abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:30
verses.text: If some heretics inculcate fasting (16) in such a way as to despise the gifts of God, and weak Christians are not to be judged for their use of flesh, those who seek the higher life (17) will find a help in abstinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:31
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:34
verses.text: The fourth proposition of Jovinianus, that all who are saved will have equal reward, is refuted (19) by the various yields of thirty, sixty, and a hundred fold in the parable of the sower, by (20) the "stars differing in glory" of 1 Cor.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:35
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:37
verses.text: It is strange (21) to find the advocate of self-indulgence now claiming equality to the saints.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:38
verses.text: But (22) as there were differences in Ezekiel between cattle and cattle, so in St.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:39
verses.text: Paul between those who built gold or stubble on the one foundation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:40
verses.text: The differences of gifts (23), of punishments (24), of guilt (25), as in Pilate and the Chief Priests, of the produce of the good seed (26), of the mansions promised in heaven (27–29), of the judgment upon sins both in the church and in Scripture (30–31), of those called at different times to the vineyard (32) are arguments for the diversity of rewards.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:41
verses.text: The parable of the talents (33) holds out as rewards differences of station, and so does the church (34) in its different orders.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:42
verses.text: Jerome now recapitulates (35) and appeals (36)against the licentious views of Jovinianus, which have already induced many virgins to break their vows; and which, as the new Roman heresy (37), he calls upon the Imperial City (38) to reject.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:44
verses.text: The second proposition of Jovinianus is that the baptized cannot be tempted by the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:45
verses.text: And to escape the imputation of folly in saying this, he adds: "But if any are tempted, it only shows that they were baptized with water, not with the Spirit, as we read was the case with Simon Magus".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:46
verses.text: Hence it is that John says, "Whosoever is begotten of God doeth no sin, because his seed abideth in him: and he cannot sin, because he is begotten of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:47
verses.text: In this the children of God are manifest, and the children of the Devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 1:48
verses.text: And at the end of the Epistle, "Whosoever is begotten of God sinneth not; but his being begotten of God keepeth him, and the evil one toucheth him not".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:2
verses.text: This would be a real difficulty and one for ever incapable of solution were it not solved by the witness of John himself, who immediately goes on to say,"My little children, guard yourselves from idols".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:3
verses.text: If everyone that is born of God sinneth not, and cannot be tempted by the devil, how is it that he bids them beware of temptation? Again in the same Epistle we read:"If we say that we have no sins, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:4
verses.text: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:5
verses.text: If we say that we have not sinned, we make him a liar, and his word is not in us".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:6
verses.text: I suppose that John was baptized and was writing to the baptized: I imagine too that all sin is of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:7
verses.text: Now John confesses himself a sinner, and hopes for forgiveness of sins after baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:8
verses.text: My friend Jovinianus says, "Touch me not, for I am clean".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:9
verses.text: What then? Does the Apostle contradict himself? By no means.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:10
verses.text: In the same passage he gives his reason for thus speaking: "My little children, these things write I unto you, that ye may not sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:11
verses.text: But if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous: and he is the propitiation for our sins; and not for ours only, but also for the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:12
verses.text: And hereby know we that we know him, if we keep his commandments.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:13
verses.text: He that saith, I know him, and keepeth not his commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:14
verses.text: But whoso keepeth his word, in him verily hath the love of God been perfected.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:15
verses.text: Hereby know we that we are in him: he that saith he abideth in him ought himself also to walk even as he walked".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:16
verses.text: My reason for telling you, little children, that everyone who is born of God sinneth not, is that you may not sin, and that you may know that so long as you sin not you abide in the birth which God has given you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:17
verses.text: Yea, they who abide in that birth cannot sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:18
verses.text: For what communion hath light with darkness? Or Christ with Belial?" As day is distinct from night, so righteousness and unrighteousness, sin and good works, Christ and Antichrist cannot blend.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:19
verses.text: If we give Christ a lodging-place in our hearts, we banish the devil from thence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:20
verses.text: If we sin and the devil enter through the gate of sin, Christ will immediately withdraw.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:21
verses.text: Hence David after sinning says:"Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation," that is, the joy which he had lost by sinning".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:22
verses.text: He who saith, I know him, and keepeth not his commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:23
verses.text: Christ is called the truth:"I am the way, the truth, and the life".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:24
verses.text: In vain do we make our boast in him whose commandments we keep not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:25
verses.text: To him that knoweth what is good, and doeth it not, it is sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:26
verses.text: As the body apart from the spirit is dead, even so faith apart from works is dead".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:27
verses.text: And we must not think it a great matter to know the only God, when even devils believe and tremble.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:28
verses.text: "He that saith he abideth in him ought himself also to walk even as he walked".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:29
verses.text: Our opponent may choose whichever of the two he likes; we give him his choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:30
verses.text: Does he abide in Christ, or not? If he abide, let him then walk as Christ walked.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:31
verses.text: But if there israshness in professing to copy the virtues of our Lord, he does not abide in Christ, for he does not walk as did Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:32
verses.text: He did not sin, neither was guile found in his mouth: when he was reviled, he reviled not again, and as a lamb is dumb before its shearer, so opened he not his mouth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:33
verses.text: To Him came the prince of this world, and found nothing in Him: although He had done no sin, God made Him sin for us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:34
verses.text: But we, according to the Epistle of James, "all stumble in many things," and"no one is pure from sin, no not if his life be but a day long".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:35
verses.text: For who will boast "that he has a clean heart? or who will be sure that he is pure from sin?" And we are held guilty after the similitude of Adam's transgression.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:36
verses.text: Hence David says,"Behold, I was shapen in iniquity, and in sin did my mother conceive me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:37
verses.text: And the blessed Job,"Though I be righteous my mouth will speak wickedness, and though I be perfect, I shall be found perverse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:38
verses.text: If I wash myself with snow water and make my hands never so clean, yet wilt thou plunge me in the ditch and mine own clothes shall abhor me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:39
verses.text: But that we may not utterly despair and think that if we sin after baptism we cannot be saved, he immediately checks the tendency:"And if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous, and he is the propitiation for our sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:40
verses.text: And not for ours only, but also for the whole world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:41
verses.text: He addresses this to baptized believers, and he promises them the Lord as an advocate for their offences.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:42
verses.text: He does not say: If you fall into sin, you have an advocate with the Father, Christ, and He is the propitiation for your sins: you might then say that he was addressing those whose baptism had been destitute of the true faith: but what he says is this, "We have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ, and he is the propitiation for our sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:43
verses.text: And not only for the sins of John and his contemporaries, but for those of the whole world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:44
verses.text: Now in "the whole world" are included apostles and all the faithful, and a clear proof is established that sin after baptism is possible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 2:45
verses.text: It is useless for us to have an advocate Jesus Christ, if sin be impossible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:2
verses.text: The apostle Peter, to whom it was said,"He that is bathed needeth not to wash again," and"Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church," through fear of a maid-servant denied Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:3
verses.text: Our Lord himself says, "Simon, Simon, behold Satan asked to have you, that he might sift you as wheat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:4
verses.text: But I made supplication for thee, that thy faith fail not".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:5
verses.text: And in the same place, "Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:6
verses.text: If you reply that this was said before the Passion, we certainly say after the Passion, in the Lord's prayer, "Forgive us our debts, as we also forgive our debtors; and lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:7
verses.text: If we do not sin after baptism, why do we ask that we may be forgiven our sins, which were already forgiven in baptism? Why do we pray that we may not enter into temptation, and that we may be delivered from the evil one, if the devil cannot tempt those who are baptized? The case is different if this prayer belongs to the Catechumens, and is not adapted to faithful Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:8
verses.text: Paul, the chosen vessel,chastised his body, and brought it into subjection, lest after preaching to others he himself should be found a reprobate, andhe tells that there was given to him "a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to buffet" him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:9
verses.text: And to the Corinthians he writes:"I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve in his craftiness, your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is toward Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:10
verses.text: And elsewhere:"But to whom ye forgive anything, I forgive also: for what I also have forgiven, if I have forgiven anything, for your sakes have I forgiven it in the person of Christ: that no advantage may be gained over us by Satan: for we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:11
verses.text: And again:"There hath no temptation taken you, but such as man can bear; but God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation make also the way of escape, that ye may be able to endure it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:12
verses.text: And,"Let him that thinketh he standeth, take heed lest he fall".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:13
verses.text: And to the Galatians:"Ye were running well; who did hinder you that ye should not obey the truth?" And elsewhere:"We would fain have come unto you, I Paul once and again; and Satan hindered us".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:14
verses.text: And to the married he says:"Be together again, that Satan tempt you not because of your incontinency".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:15
verses.text: And again:"But I say, walk by the Spirit and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:16
verses.text: For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh; for these are contrary the one to the other: that ye may not do the things that ye would".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:17
verses.text: We are a compound of the two, and must endure the strife of the two substances.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:18
verses.text: And to the Ephesians:"Our wrestling is not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities, against the powers, against the world-rulers of this darkness, against the spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:19
verses.text: Does any one think that we are safe, and that it is right to fall asleep when once we have been baptized? And so, too, in the epistle to the Hebrews:"For as touching those who were once enlightened and tasted of the heavenly gift, and were made partakers of the Holy Ghost, and tasted the good word of God, and the powers of the age to come, and then fell away, it is impossible to renew them again unto repentance; seeing they crucify to themselves the Son of God afresh, and put him to an open shame".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:20
verses.text: Surely we cannot deny that they have been baptized who have been illuminated, and have tasted the heavenly gift, and have been made partakers of the Holy Spirit, and have tasted the good word of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:21
verses.text: But if the baptized cannot sin, how is it now that the Apostle says, "And have fallen away"?Montanus andNovatus would smile at this, for they contend that it is impossible to renew again through repentance those who have crucified to themselves the Son of God, and put Him to an open shame.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:22
verses.text: He therefore corrects this mistake by saying:"But, beloved, we are persuaded better things of you, and things that accompany salvation, though we thus speak; for God is not unrighteous to forget your work and the love which ye shewed towards his name, in that ye ministered unto the Saints, and still do minister".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:23
verses.text: And truly the unrighteousness of God would be great, if He merely punished sin, and did not welcome good works.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:24
verses.text: I have so spoken, says the Apostle, to withdraw you from your sins, and to make you more careful through fear of despair.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:25
verses.text: But, beloved, I am persuaded better things of you, and things that accompany salvation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:26
verses.text: For it is not accordant with the righteousness of God to forget good works, and the fact that you have ministered and do minister to the Saints for His name's sake, and to remember sins only.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:27
verses.text: The Apostle James also, knowing that the baptized can be tempted, and fall of their own free choice, says:"Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he hath been approved, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord promised to them that love him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:28
verses.text: And that we may not think that we are tempted by God, as we read in Genesis Abraham was, he adds: "Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil, and He Himself tempteth no man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:29
verses.text: But each man is tempted when he is drawn away by his own lust and enticed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:30
verses.text: Then the lust, when it hath conceived, beareth sin: and the sin, when it is full grown, bringeth forth death".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:31
verses.text: God created us with free will, and we are not forced by necessity either to virtue or to vice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:32
verses.text: Otherwise, if there be necessity, there is no crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:33
verses.text: As in good works it is God who brings them to perfection, for it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that pitieth and gives us help that we may be able to reach the goal: so in things wicked and sinful, the seeds within us give the impulse, and these are brought to maturity by the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:34
verses.text: When he sees that we are building upon the foundation of Christ, hay, wood, stubble, then he applies the match.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:35
verses.text: Let us then build gold, silver, costly stones, and he will not venture to tempt us: although even thus there is not sure and safe possession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:36
verses.text: For the lion lurks in ambush to slay the innocent".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:37
verses.text: Potters' vessels are proved by the furnace, and just men by the trial of tribulation".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:38
verses.text: And in another place it is written:"My son, when thou comest to serve the Lord, prepare thyself for temptation".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:39
verses.text: Again, the same James says:"Be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:40
verses.text: For if any one is a hearer of the word, and not a doer, he is like unto a man beholding his natural face in a mirror: for he beholdeth himself, and goeth away, and straightway forgetteth what manner of man he was".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:41
verses.text: It was useless to warn them to add works to faith, if they could not sin after baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:42
verses.text: He tells us that"whosoever shall keep the whole law, and yet stumble in one point, he is become guilty of all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:43
verses.text: Which of us is without sin?"God hath shut up all unto disobedience, that he might have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:44
verses.text: Peter also says:"The Lord knows how to deliver the godly out of temptation".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:45
verses.text: And concerning false teachers:"These are springs without water, and mists driven by a storm; for whom the blackness of darkness hath been reserved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:46
verses.text: For, uttering proud words of vanity, they entice in the lusts of the flesh, by lasciviousness, those who had just escaped, and have turned back to error".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:47
verses.text: Does not the Apostle in these words seem to you to have depicted the new party of ignorance? For, as it were, they open the fountains of knowledge and yet have no water: they promise a shower of doctrine like prophetic clouds which have been visited by the truth of God, and are driven by the storms of devils and vices.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:48
verses.text: They speak great things, and their talk is nothing but pride:"But every one is unclean with God who is lifted up in his own heart".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:49
verses.text: Like those who had just escaped from their sins, they return to their own error, and persuade men to luxury, and to the delights of eating and the gratification of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:50
verses.text: For who is not glad to hear them say: "Let us eat and drink, and reign for ever"? The wise and prudent they call corrupt, but pay more attention to the honey-tongued.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:51
verses.text: John the apostle, or rather the Saviour in the person of John, writes thus to the angel of the Church of Ephesus:"I know thy works and thy toil and patience, and that thou didst bear for my name's sake, and hast not grown weary.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:52
verses.text: But I have this against thee, that thou didst leave thy first love.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:53
verses.text: Remember therefore from whence thou art fallen, and repent, and do the first works; or else I will come to thee, and will move thy candlestick out of its place, except thou repent".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:54
verses.text: Similarly He urges the other churches, Smyrna, Pergamos, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, Laodicea, to repentance, and threatens them unless they return to the former works.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:55
verses.text: And in Sardis He says He has a few who have not defiled their garments, and they shall walk with Him in white, for they are worthy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 3:56
verses.text: But they to whom He says: "Remember from whence thou art fallen"; and, "Behold the devil is about to cast some of you into prison, that ye may be tried"; and, "I know where thou dwellest, even where Satan's throne is"; and, "Remember how thou hast received, and didst hear, and keep it, and repent," and so on, were of course believers, and baptized, who once stood, but fell through sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:2
verses.text: I delayed for a little while the production of proofs from the Old Testament, because, wherever the Old Testament is against them they are accustomed to cry out that the Law and the Prophets were until John.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:3
verses.text: But who does not know that under the other dispensation of God all the saints of past times were of equal merit with Christians at the present day? As Abraham in days gone by pleased God in wedlock, so virgins now please him in perpetual virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:4
verses.text: He served the Law and his own times; let us now serve the Gospel and our times,upon whom the ends of the ages have come.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:5
verses.text: David the chosen one, the man after God's own heart, who had performed all His pleasure, and who in a certain psalm had said, "Judge me, O Lord, for I have walked in mine integrity: I have trusted also in the Lord and shall not slide.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:6
verses.text: Examine me, O Lord, and prove me; try my reins and my heart," even he was afterwards tempted by the devil; and repenting of his sin said, "Have mercy upon me, O God, according to thy loving-kindness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:7
verses.text: He would have a great sin blotted out by great loving-kindness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:8
verses.text: Solomon, beloved of the Lord, and to whom God had twice revealed Himself, because he loved women forsook the love of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:9
verses.text: It is related in theBook of Days that Manasses the wicked king was restored after the Babylonish captivity to his former rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:10
verses.text: And Josiah, a holy man, was slain by the king of Egypt on the plain of Megiddo.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:11
verses.text: Joshua also, the son of Josedech and high-priest, although he was a type of our Saviour Who bore our sins, and united to Himself a church of alien birth from among the Gentiles, is nevertheless, according to the letter of Scripture, represented in filthy garments after he attained to the priesthood, and with the devil standing at his right hand; and white raiment is afterwards restored to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:12
verses.text: It is needless to tell how Moses and Aaronoffended God at the water of strife, and did not enter the land of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:13
verses.text: For the blessed Job relates that even the angels and every creature can sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:14
verses.text: Shall mortal man," he says, "be just before God? Shall a man be spotless in his works? If he putteth no trust in his servants, and chargeth his angels with folly, how much more them that dwell in houses of clay," amongst whom are we, and made of the same clay too".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:15
verses.text: The life of man is a warfare upon earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:16
verses.text: Lucifer fell who was sending to all nations, and he who was nurtured in a paradise of delight as one of the twelve precious stones, was wounded and went down to hell from the mount of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:17
verses.text: Hence the Saviour says in the Gospel:"I beheld Satan falling as lightning from heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:18
verses.text: If he fell who stood on so sublime a height, who may not fall? If there are falls in heaven, how much more on earth! And yet though Lucifer be fallen (the old serpent after his fall),"his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the muscles of his belly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:19
verses.text: The great trees are overshadowed by him, and he sleepeth beside the reed, the rush, and the sedge".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:20
verses.text: He is king over all things that are in the waters—that is to say in the seat of pleasure and luxury, of propagation of children, and of the fertilisation of the marriage bed".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:21
verses.text: For who can strip off his outer garment? Who can open the doors of his face? Nations fatten upon him, and the tribes of Phenicia divide him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:22
verses.text: And lest haply the reader in his secret thought might imagine that those tribes of Phenicia and peoples of Ethiopia only are meant by those to whom the dragon was given for food, we immediately find a reference to those who are crossing the sea of this world, and are hastening to reach the haven of salvation:"His head stands in the ships of the fishermen like an anvil that cannot be wearied:he counteth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:23
verses.text: And all the gold of the sea under him is as mire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:24
verses.text: He maketh the deep to boil like a pot: he values the sea like a pot of ointment, and the blackness of the deep as a captive.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:25
verses.text: He beholdeth everything that is high".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:26
verses.text: And my friend Jovinianus thinks he can gain an easy mastery over him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:27
verses.text: Why speak of holy men and angels, who, being creatures of God, are of course capable of sin? He dared to tempt the Son of God, and though smitten through and through with our Lord's first and second answer, nevertheless raised his head, and when thrice wounded, withdrew only for a time, and deferred rather than removed the temptation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 4:28
verses.text: And we flatter ourselves on the ground of our baptism, which though it put away the sins of the past, cannot keep us for the time to come, unless the baptized keep their hearts with all diligence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:2
verses.text: At length we have arrived at the question of food, and are confronted by our third difficulty.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:3
verses.text: "All things were created to serve for the use of mortal men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:4
verses.text: And as man, a rational animal, in a sense the owner and tenant of the world, is subject to God, and worships his Creator, so all things living were created either for the food of men, or for clothing, or for tilling the earth, or conveying the fruits thereof, or to be the companions of man, and hence, because they are man's helpers, they have their name jumenta.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:5
verses.text: 'What is man,' says David, 'that thou art mindful of him? And the son of man, that thou visitest him? For thou hast made him but little lower than the angels, and crownest him with glory and honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:6
verses.text: Thou madest him to have dominion over the works of thine hands; thou hast put all things under his feet: all sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field: the fowl of the air, and the fish of the sea, whatsoever passeth through the paths of the seas.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:7
verses.text: ' Granted, he says, that the ox was created for ploughing, the horse for riding, the dog for watching, goats for their milk, sheep for their fleeces.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:8
verses.text: What is the use of swine if we may not eat their flesh? of roes, stags, fallow-deer, boars, hares, and such like game? of geese, wild and tame? of wild ducks andfig-peckers? of woodcocks? of coots? of thrushes? Why do hens run about our houses? If they are not eaten, all these creatures were created by God for nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:9
verses.text: But what need is there of argument when Scripture clearly teaches that every moving creature, like herbs and vegetables, were given to us for food, and the Apostle cries aloud 'All things are clean to the clean, and nothing is to be rejected, if it be received with thanksgiving,' andtells us that men will come in the last days, forbidding to marry, and to eat meats, which God created for use? The Lord himself was called by the Pharisees a wine-bibber and a glutton, the friend of publicans and sinners, because he did not decline the invitation of Zacchaeus to dinner, and went to the marriage-feast.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:10
verses.text: But it is a different matter if, as you may foolishly contend, he went to the dinner intending to fast, and after the manner of deceivers said, I eat this, not that; I do not drink the wine which I created out of water.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:11
verses.text: He did not make water, but wine, the type of his blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:12
verses.text: After the resurrection he ate a fish and part of a honey-comb, not sesame nuts and service-berries.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:13
verses.text: The apostle, Peter, did not wait like a Jew for the stars to peep, but went upon the house-top to dine at the sixth hour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:14
verses.text: Paul in the ship broke bread, not dried figs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:15
verses.text: When Timothy's stomach was out of order, he advised him to drink wine, not perry.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 5:16
verses.text: In abstaining from meats they please their own fancy: as though superstitious Gentiles did not observe therites of abstinence connected with the Mother of the Gods and with Isis".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:2
verses.text: I will follow in detail the views now expounded, and before I come to Scripture and show by it that fasting is pleasing to God, and chastity accepted by him, I will meet philosophic argument with argument, and will prove that we are not followers of Empedocles and Pythagoras, who on account of their doctrine of the transmigration of souls think nothing which lives and moves should be eaten, and look upon him who fells a fir-tree or an oak as equally guilty with the parricide or the poisoner: but that we worship our Creator Who made all things for the use of man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:3
verses.text: And as the ox was created for ploughing, the horse for riding, dogs for watching, goats for milk, sheep for their wool: so it was with swine and stags, and roes and hares, and other animals: but the immediate purpose of their creation was not that they might serve for food, but for other uses of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:4
verses.text: For if everything that moves and lives was made for food, and prepared for the stomach, let my opponents tell me why elephants, lions, leopards, and wolves were created; why vipers, scorpions, bugs, lice, and fleas; why the vulture, the eagle, the crow, the hawk; why whales, dolphins, seals, and small snails were created.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:5
verses.text: Which of us ever eats the flesh of a lion, a viper, a vulture, a stork, a kite, or the worms that crawl upon our shores? As then these have their proper uses, so may we say that other beasts, fishes, birds, were created not for eating, but for medicine.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:6
verses.text: In short, to how many uses the flesh of vipers, from which we make our antidotes against poison, may be applied, physicians know well.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:7
verses.text: Ivory dust is an ingredient in many remedies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:8
verses.text: Hyena's gall restores brightness to the eyes, and its dung and that of dogs cures gangrenous wounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:9
verses.text: And (it may seem strange to the reader) Galen asserts in his treatise on Simples, that human dung is of service in a multitude of cases.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:10
verses.text: Naturalists say that snake-skin, boiled in oil, gives wonderful relief in ear-ache.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:11
verses.text: What to the uninitiated seems so useless as a bug? Yet, suppose a leech to have fastened on the throat, as soon as the odour of a bug is inhaled the leech is vomited out, and difficulty in urinating is relieved by the same application.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:12
verses.text: As for the fat of pigs, geese, fowls, and pheasants, how useful they are is told in all medical works, and if you read these books you will see there that the vulture has as many curative properties as it has limbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:13
verses.text: Peacock's dung allays the inflammation of gout.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:14
verses.text: Cranes, storks, eagle's gall, hawk's blood, the ostrich, frogs, chameleons, swallow's dung and flesh—in what diseases these are suitable remedies, I could tell if it were my purpose to discuss bodily ailments and their cure.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:15
verses.text: If you think proper you may read Aristotle andTheophrastus in prose, orMarcellus of Side, and ourFlavius, who discourse on these subjects in hexameter verse; thesecond Pliny also, andDioscorides, and others, both naturalists and physicians, who assign to every herb, every stone, every animal whether reptile, bird, or fish, its own use in the art of which they treat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:16
verses.text: So then when you ask me why the pig was created, I immediately reply, as if two boys were disputing, by asking you why were vipers and scorpions? You must not judge that anything from the hand of God is superfluous, because there are many beasts and birds which your palate rejects.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:17
verses.text: But this may perhaps look more like contentiousness and pugnacity than truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:18
verses.text: Let me tell you therefore that pigs and wild-boars, and stags, and the rest of living creatures were created, that soldiers, athletes, sailors, rhetoricians, miners, and other slaves of hard toil, who need physical strength, might have food: and also those who carry arms and provisions, who wear themselves out with the work of hand or foot, who ply the oar, who need good lungs to shout and speak, who level mountains and sleep out rain or fair.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:19
verses.text: But our religion does not train boxers, athletes, sailors, soldiers, or ditchers, but followers of wisdom, who devote themselves to the worship of God, and know why they were created and are in the world from which they are impatient to depart.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:20
verses.text: Hence also the Apostle says: "When I am weak, then am I strong".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:21
verses.text: And "Though our outward man is decaying, yet our inward man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:22
verses.text: And "I have the desire to depart and be with Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:23
verses.text: And, "Make not provision for the flesh to fulfil the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:24
verses.text: Are all commandednot to have two coats, nor food in their scrip, money in their purse, a staff in the hand, shoes on the feet? or to sell all they possess and give to the poor, and follow Jesus? Of course not: but the command is for those who wish to be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:25
verses.text: On the contrary John the Baptist lays down one rule for the soldiers, another for the publicans.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:26
verses.text: But the Lord says in the Gospel to him who had boasted of having kept the whole law:"If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell all that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come, follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:27
verses.text: That He might not seem to lay a heavy burden on unwilling shoulders, He sent His hearer away with full power to please himself, saying "If thou wilt be perfect".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:28
verses.text: And so I too say to you: If you wish to be perfect, it is good not to drink wine, and eat flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:29
verses.text: If you wish to be perfect, it is better to enrich the mind than to stuff the body.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:30
verses.text: But if you are an infant and fond of the cooks and their preparations, no one will snatch the dainties out of your mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:31
verses.text: Eat and drink, and, if you like, with Israel rise up and play, and sing"Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we shall die".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:32
verses.text: Let him eat and drink, who looks for death when he has feasted, and who says with Epicurus, "There is nothing after death, and death itself is nothing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:33
verses.text: We believe Paul when he says in tones of thunder:"Meats for the belly, and the belly for meats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 6:34
verses.text: But God will destroy both them and it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:2
verses.text: I have quoted these few passages of Scripture to show that we are at one with the philosophers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:3
verses.text: But who does not know that no universal law of nature regulates the food of all nations, and that each eats those things of which it has abundance? For instance, the Arabians and Saracens, and all the wild tribes of the desert live on camel's milk and flesh: for the camel, to suit the climate and barren soil of those regions, is easily bred and reared.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:4
verses.text: They think it wicked to eat the flesh of swine.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:5
verses.text: Why? Because pigs which fatten on acorns, chestnuts, roots of ferns, and barley, are seldom or never found among them: and if they were found, they would not afford the nourishment of which we spoke just now.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:6
verses.text: The exact opposite is the case with the northern peoples.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:7
verses.text: If you were to force them to eat the flesh of asses and camels, they would think it the same as though they were compelled to devour a wolf or a crow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:8
verses.text: In Pontus and Phrygia a pater-familias pays a good price for fat white worms with blackish heads, which breed in decayed wood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:9
verses.text: And as with us the woodcock and fig-pecker, the mullet and scar, are reputed delicacies, so with them it is a luxury to eat thexylophagus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:10
verses.text: Again, because throughout the glowing wastes of the desert clouds of locusts are found, it is customary with the peoples of the East and of Libya to feed on locusts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:11
verses.text: John the Baptist proves the truth of this.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:12
verses.text: Compel a Phrygian or a native of Pontus to eat a locust, and he will think it scandalous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:13
verses.text: Force a Syrian, an African, or Arabian to swallow worms, he will have the same contempt for them as for flies, millepedes, and lizards, although the Syrians are accustomed to eat land-crocodiles, and the Africans even green lizards.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:14
verses.text: In Egypt and Palestine, owing to the scarcity of cattle no one eats beef, or makes the flesh of bulls or oxen, or calves, a portion of their food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:15
verses.text: Moreover, in my province it is considered a crime to eat veal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:16
verses.text: Accordingly the Emperor Valens recently promulgated a law throughout the East, prohibiting the killing and eating of calves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:17
verses.text: He had in view the interests of agriculture, and wished to check the bad practice of the commoner sort of the people who imitated the Jews in devouring the flesh of calves, instead of fowls and sucking pigs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:18
verses.text: The Nomad tribes, and theTroglodytes, and Scythians, and the barbarousHuns with whom we have recently become acquainted, eat flesh half raw.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:19
verses.text: Moreover the Icthyophagi, a wandering race on the shores of the Red Sea, broil fish on the stones made hot by the sun, and subsist on this poor food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:20
verses.text: TheSarmatians, theChuadi, theVandals, and countless other races, delight in the flesh of horses and wolves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:21
verses.text: Why should I speak of other nations when I myself, a youth on a visit to Gaul, heard that the Atticoti, a British tribe, eat human flesh, and that although they find herds of swine, and droves of large or small cattle in the woods, it is their custom to cut off the buttocks of the shepherds and the breasts of their women, and to regard them as the greatest delicacies? The Scots have no wives of their own; as though they read Plato's Republic and took Cato for their leader, no man among them has his own wife, but like beasts they indulge their lust to their hearts' content.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:22
verses.text: The Persians, Medes, Indians, and Ethiopians, peoples on a par with Rome itself, have intercourse with mothers and grandmothers, with daughters and granddaughters.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:23
verses.text: TheMassagetae andDerbices think those persons most unhappy who die of sickness—and when parents, kindred, or friends reach old age, they are murdered and devoured.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:24
verses.text: It is thought better that they should be eaten by the people themselves than by the worms.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:25
verses.text: TheTibareni crucify those whom they have loved before when they have grown old.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:26
verses.text: TheHyrcani throw them out half alive to the birds and dogs: the Caspians leave them dead for the same beasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:27
verses.text: The Scythians bury alive with the remains of the dead those who were beloved of the deceased.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:28
verses.text: The Bactrians throw their old men to dogs which they rear for the very purpose, and when Stasanor, Alexander's general, wished to correct the practice, he almost lost his province.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:29
verses.text: Force an Egyptian to drink sheep's milk: drive, if you can, a Pelusiote to eat an onion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:30
verses.text: Almost every city in Egypt venerates its own beasts and monsters, and whatever be the object of worship, that they think inviolable and sacred.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:31
verses.text: Hence it is that their towns also are named after animals Leonto, Cyno, Lyco, Busyris, Thmuis, which is, being interpreted, a he-goat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:32
verses.text: And to make us understand what sort of gods Egypt always welcomed, one of their cities was recently calledAntinous after Hadrian's favourite.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:33
verses.text: You see clearly then that not only in eating, but also in burial, in wedlock, and in every department of life, each race follows its own practice and peculiar usages, and takes that for the law of nature which is most familiar to it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:34
verses.text: But suppose all nations alike ate flesh, and let that be everywhere lawful which the place produces.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:35
verses.text: How does it concern us whose conversation is in heaven? who, as well as Pythagoras and Empedocles and all lovers of wisdom, are not bound to the circumstances of our birth, but of our new birth: who by abstinence subjugate our refractory flesh, eager to follow the allurements of lust? The eating of flesh, and drinking of wine, and fulness of stomach, is the seed-plot of lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 7:36
verses.text: And so the comic poet says, "Venus shivers unless Ceres and Bacchus be with her".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:2
verses.text: Through the five senses, as through open windows, vice has access to the soul.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:3
verses.text: The metropolis and citadel of the mind cannot be taken unless the enemy have previously entered by its doors.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:4
verses.text: The soul is distressed by the disorder they produce, and is led captive by sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:5
verses.text: If any one delights in the sports of the circus, or the struggles of athletes, the versatility of actors, the figure of women, in splendid jewels, dress, silver and gold, and other things of the kind, the liberty of the soul is lost through the windows of the eyes, and the prophet's words are fulfilled:"Death is come up into our windows".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:6
verses.text: Again, our sense of hearing is flattered by the tones of various instruments and the modulations of the voice; and whatever enters the ear by the songs of poets and comedians, by the pleasantries and verses of pantomimic actors, weakens the manly fibre of the mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:7
verses.text: Then, again, no one but a profligate denies that the profligate and licentious find a delight in sweet odours, different sorts of incense, fragrant balsam,kuphi,oenanthe, and musk, which is nothing but the skin of a foreign rat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:8
verses.text: And who does not know that gluttony is the mother of avarice, and, as it were, fetters the heart and keeps it pressed down upon the earth? For the sake of a temporary gratification of the appetite, land and sea are ransacked, and we toil and sweat our lives through, that we may send down our throats honey-wine and costly food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:9
verses.text: The desire to handle other men's persons, and the burning lust for women, is a passion bordering on insanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:10
verses.text: To gratify this sense we languish, grow angry, throw ourselves about with joy, indulge envy, engage in rivalry, are filled with anxiety, and when we have terminated the pleasure with more or less repentance, we once more take fire, and want to do that which we again regret doing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 8:11
verses.text: Where, then, that which we may call the thin edge of disturbance, has entered the citadel of the mind through these doors, what will become of its liberty, its endurance, its thought of God, particularly since the sense of touch can picture to itself even bygone pleasures, and through the recollection of vice forces the soul to take part in them, and after a manner to practice what it does not actually commit?.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:2
verses.text: At the call of reasoning such as this, many philosophers have forsaken the crowded cities, and their pleasure gardens in the suburbs with well-watered grounds, shady trees, twittering birds, crystal fountains, murmuring brooks, and many charms for eye and ear, lest through luxury and abundance of riches, the firmness of the mind should be enfeebled, and its purity debauched.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:3
verses.text: For there is no good in frequently seeing objects which may one day lead to your captivity, or in making trial of things which you would find it hard to do without.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:4
verses.text: Even the Pythagoreans shunned company of this kind and were wont to dwell in solitary places in the desert.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:5
verses.text: The Platonists also and Stoics lived in the groves and porticos of temples, that, admonished by the sanctity of their restricted abode, they might think of nothing but virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:6
verses.text: Plato, moreover, himself, whenDiogenes trampled on his couches with muddy feet (he being a rich man), chose a house calledAcademia at some distance from the city, in a spot not only lonely but unhealthy, so that he might have leisure for philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:7
verses.text: His object was that by constant anxiety about sickness the assaults of lust might be defeated, and that his disciples might experience no pleasure but that afforded by the things they learned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:8
verses.text: We have read of some who took out their own eyes lest through sight they might lose the contemplation of philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:9
verses.text: Hence it was thatCrates the famous Theban, after throwing into the sea a considerable weight of gold, exclaimed, "Go to the bottom, ye evil lusts: I will drown you that you may not drown me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:10
verses.text: But if anyone thinks to enjoy keenly meat and drink in excess, and at the same time to devote himself to philosophy, that is to say, to live in luxury and yet not to be hampered by the vices attendant on luxury, he deceives himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:11
verses.text: For if it be the case that even when far distant from them we are frequently caught in the snares of nature, and are compelled to desire those things of which we have a scant supply: what folly it is to think we are free when we are surrounded by the nets of pleasure! We think of what we see, hear, smell, taste, handle, and are led to desire the thing which affords us pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:12
verses.text: That the mind sees and hears, and that we can neither hear nor see anything unless our senses are fixed upon the objects of sight and hearing, is an old saw.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:13
verses.text: It is difficult, or rather impossible, when we are swimming in luxury and pleasure not to think of what we are doing: and it is an idle pretence which some men put forwardthat they can take their fill of pleasure with their faith and purity and mental uprightness unimpaired.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 9:14
verses.text: It is a violation of nature to revel in pleasure, and the Apostle gives a caution against this very thing when he says, "She that giveth herself to pleasure is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:2
verses.text: The bodily senses are like horses madly racing, but the soul like a charioteer holds the reins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:3
verses.text: And as horses without a driver go at break-neck speed, so the body if it be not governed by the reasonable soul rushes to its own destruction.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:4
verses.text: The philosophers make use of another illustration of the relations between soul and body;they say the body is a boy, the soul his tutor.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:5
verses.text: Hence thehistorian tells us "that our soul directs, our body serves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:6
verses.text: The one we have in common with the gods, the other with the beasts".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:7
verses.text: So then unless the vices of youth and boyhood are regulated by the wisdom of the tutor, every effort and every impulse sets strongly in the direction of wantonness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:8
verses.text: We might lose four of the senses and yet live,—that is we could do without sight, hearing, smell, and the pleasures of touch.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:9
verses.text: But a human being cannot subsist without tasting food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:10
verses.text: It follows that reason must be present, that we may take food of such a kind and in such quantities as will not burden the body, or hinder the free movement of the soul: for it is the way with us that we eat, and walk, and sleep, and digest our food, and afterwards in the fulness of blood have to bear the spur of lust".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:11
verses.text: Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:12
verses.text: Whosoever has much to do with these is not wise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:13
verses.text: And we should not take such food as is difficult of digestion, or such as when eaten will give us reason to complain that we got it and lost it with much effort.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:14
verses.text: The preparation of vegetables, fruit, and pulse is easy, and does not require the skill of expensive cooks: our bodies are nourished by them with little trouble on our part; and, if taken in moderation, such food is easier to digest, and at less cost, because it does not stimulate the appetite, and therefore is not devoured with avidity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:15
verses.text: No one has his stomach inflated or overloaded if he eats only one or two dishes, and those inexpensive ones: such a condition comes of pampering the taste with a variety of meats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:16
verses.text: The smells of the kitchen may induce us to eat, but when hunger is satisfied, they make us their slaves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 10:17
verses.text: Hence gorging gives rise to disease: and many persons find relief for the discomfort of gluttony in emetics,—what they disgraced themselves by putting in, they with still greater disgrace put out.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:2
verses.text: Hippocrates in his Aphorisms teaches that stout persons of a coarse habit of body, when once they have attained their full growth, unless the plethora be quickly relieved by blood-letting, develop tendencies to paralysis and the worst forms of disease: they must therefore be bled, that there may be room for fresh growth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:3
verses.text: For it is not the nature of our bodies to continue in one stay, but go on either to increase or decrease, and no animal can live which is incapable of growth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:4
verses.text: WhenceGalen, a very learned man and the commentator on Hippocrates, says in his exhortation to the practice of medicine that athletes whose whole life and art consists in stuffing cannot live long, nor be healthy: and that their souls enveloped with superfluous blood and fat, and as it were covered with mud, have no refined or heavenly thoughts, but are always intent upon gluttonous and voracious feasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:5
verses.text: Diogenes maintains that tyrants do not bring about revolutions in cities, and foment wars civil or foreign for the sake of a simple diet of vegetables and fruits, but for costly meats and the delicacies of the table.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:6
verses.text: And, strange to say, Epicurus, the defender of pleasure, in all his books speaks of nothing but vegetables and fruits; and he says that we ought to live on cheap food because the preparation of sumptuous banquets of flesh involves great care and suffering, and greater pains attend the search for such delicacies than pleasures the consumption of them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:7
verses.text: Our bodies need only something to eat and drink.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:8
verses.text: Where there is bread and water, and the like, nature is satisfied.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:9
verses.text: Whatever more there may be does not go to meet the wants of life, but are ministers to vicious pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:10
verses.text: Eating and drinking does not quench the longing for luxuries, but appeases hunger and thirst.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:11
verses.text: Persons who feed on flesh want also gratifications not found in flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:12
verses.text: But they who adopt a simple diet do not look for flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:13
verses.text: Further, we cannot devote ourselves to wisdom if our thoughts are running on a well-laden table, the supply of which requires an excess of work and anxiety.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:14
verses.text: The wants of nature are soon satisfied: cold and hunger can be banished with simple food and clothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:15
verses.text: Hence the Apostle says: "Having food and clothing let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:16
verses.text: Delicacies and the various dishes of the feast are the nurses of avarice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:17
verses.text: The soul greatly exults when you are content with little: you have the world beneath your feet, and can exchange all its power, its feasts, and its lusts, the objects for which men rake money together, for common food, and make up for them all with a sack-cloth shirt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:18
verses.text: Take away the luxurious feasting and the gratification of lust, and no one will want riches to be used either in the belly, or beneath it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:19
verses.text: The invalid only regains his health by diminishing and carefully selecting his food, i-e:, in medical phrase, by adopting a "slender diet".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:20
verses.text: The same food that recovers health, can preserve it, for no one can imagine vegetables to be the cause of disease.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:21
verses.text: And if vegetables do not give the strength of Milo of Crotona—a strength supplied and nourished by meat—what need has a wise man and a Christian philosopher of such strength as is required by athletes and soldiers, and which, if he had it, would only stimulate to vice? Let those persons deem meat accordant with health who wish to gratify their lust, and who, sunk in filthy pleasure, are always at heat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:22
verses.text: What a Christian wants is health, but not superfluous strength.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:23
verses.text: And it ought not to disturb us if we find but few supporters; for the pure and temperate are as rare as good and faithful friends, and virtue is always scarce.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:24
verses.text: Study the temperance ofFabricius, or the poverty ofCurius, and in a great city you will find few worthy of your imitation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 11:25
verses.text: You need not fear that if you do not eat flesh, fowlers and hunters will have learnt their craft in vain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:2
verses.text: We have read that some who suffered with disease of the joints and with gouty humours recovered their health by proscribing delicacies, and coming down to a simple board and mean food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:3
verses.text: For they were then free from the worry of managing a house and from unlimited feasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:4
verses.text: Horace makes fun of the longing for food which when eaten leaves nothing but regret.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:5
verses.text: "Scorn pleasure; she but hurts when bought with pain".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:6
verses.text: And when, in the delightful retirement of the country, by way of satirizing voluptuous men, he described himself as plump and fat, his sportive verse ran thus:  "Pay me a visit if you want to laugh,  You'll find me fat and sleek with well-dress'd hide,  Like any pig from Epicurus' sty".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:7
verses.text: But even if our food be the commonest, we must avoid repletion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:8
verses.text: For nothing is so destructive to the mind as a full belly, fermenting like a wine vat and giving forth its gases on all sides.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:9
verses.text: What sort of fasting is it, or what refreshment is there after fasting, when we are blown out with yesterday's dinner, and ourstomach is made a factory for the closet? We wish to get credit for protracted abstinence, and all the while we devour so much that a day and a night can scarcely digest it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 12:10
verses.text: The proper name to give it is not fasting, but rather debauch and rank indigestion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:2
verses.text: Dicaearchus in his book of Antiquities, describing Greece, relates that under Saturn, that is in the Golden Age, when the ground brought forth all things abundantly, no one ate flesh, but every one lived on field produce and fruits which the earth bore of itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:3
verses.text: Xenophon in eight books narrates the life of Cyrus, King of the Persians, and asserts that they supported life on barley, cress, salt, and black bread.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:4
verses.text: Both the aforesaid Xenophon, Theophrastus, and almost all the Greek writers testify to the frugal diet of the Spartans.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:5
verses.text: Chaeremon the Stoic, a man of great eloquence, has a treatise on the life of the ancient priests of Egypt, who, he says, laid aside all worldly business and cares, and were ever in the temple, studying nature and the regulating causes of the heavenly bodies; they never had intercourse with women; they never from the time they began to devote themselves to the divine service set eyes on their kindred and relations, nor even saw their children; they always abstained from flesh and wine, on account of the light-headedness and dizziness which a small quantity of food caused, and especially to avoid the stimulation of the lustful appetite engendered by this meat and drink.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:6
verses.text: They seldom ate bread, that they might not load the stomach.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:7
verses.text: And whenever they ate it, they mixed pounded hyssop with all that they took, so that the action of its warmth might diminish the weight of the heavier food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:8
verses.text: They used no oil except with vegetables, and then only in small quantities, to mitigate the unpalatable taste.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:9
verses.text: What need, he says, to speak of birds, when they avoided even eggs and milk as flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:10
verses.text: The one, they said, was liquid flesh, the other was blood with the colour changed? Their bed was made of palm-leaves, called by them baiae: a sloping footstool laid upon the ground served for a pillow, and they could go without food for two or three days.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 13:11
verses.text: The humours of the body which arise from sedentary habits were dried up by reducing their diet to an extreme point.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:2
verses.text: Josephus in the second book of the history of the Jewish captivity, and in the eighteenth book of the Antiquities, and the two treatises against Apion, describes three sects of the Jews, the Pharisees, Sadducees, and Essenes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:3
verses.text: On the last of these he bestows wondrous praise because they practised perpetual abstinence from wives, wine, and flesh, and made a second nature of their daily fast.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:4
verses.text: Philo, too, a man of great learning, published a treatise of his own on their mode of life.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:5
verses.text: Neanthes of Cizycus, andAsclepiades of Cyprus, at the time when Pygmalion ruled over the East, relate that the eating of flesh was unknown.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:6
verses.text: Eubulus, also, who wrote the history ofMithras in many volumes, relates that among the Persians there are three kinds of Magi, the first of whom, those of greatest learning and eloquence, take no food except meal and vegetables.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:7
verses.text: At Eleusis it is customary to abstain from fowls and fish and certain fruits.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:8
verses.text: Bardesanes, a Babylonian, divides the Gymnosophists of India into two classes, the one called Brahmans, the other Samaneans, who are so rigidly self-restrained that they support themselves either with the fruit of trees which grow on the banks of the Ganges, or with common food of rice or flour, and when the king visits them, he is wont to adore them, and thinks the peace of his country depends upon their prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:9
verses.text: Euripides relates that the prophets of Jupiter in Crete abstained not only from flesh, but also from cooked food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:10
verses.text: Xenocrates the philosopher writes that at Athens out of all the laws ofTriptolemus only three precepts remain in the temple of Ceres: respect to parents, reverence for the gods, and abstinence from flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:11
verses.text: Orpheus in his song utterly denounces the eating of flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:12
verses.text: I might speak of the frugality of Pythagoras, Socrates, andAntisthenes to our confusion: but it would be tedious, and would require a work to itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:13
verses.text: At all events this is the Antisthenes who, after teaching rhetoric with renown, on hearing Socrates, is related to have said to his disciples, "Go, and seek a master, for I have now found one".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:14
verses.text: He immediately, sold what he had, divided the proceeds among the people, and kept nothing for himself but a small cloak.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:15
verses.text: Of his poverty and toil Xenophon in the Symposium is a witness, and so are his countless treatises, some philosophical, some rhetorical.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:16
verses.text: His most famous follower was the great Diogenes, who was mightier than King Alexander in that he conquered human nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:17
verses.text: For Antisthenes would not take a single pupil, and when he could not get rid of the persistent Diogenes he threatened him with a stick if he did not depart.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:18
verses.text: The latter is said to have laid down his head and said, "No stick will be hard enough to prevent me from following you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:19
verses.text: Satyrus, the biographer of illustrious men, relates that Diogenes to guard himself against the cold, folded his cloak double: his scrip was his pantry: and when aged he carried a stick to support his feeble frame, and was commonly called "Old Hand-to-mouth," because to that very hour he begged and received food from any one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:20
verses.text: His home was the gateways and city arcades.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:21
verses.text: And when he wriggled into his tub, he would joke about his movable house that adapted itself to the seasons.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:22
verses.text: For when the weather was cold he used to turn the mouth of the tub towards the south: in summer towards the north; and whatever the direction of the sun might be, that way the palace of Diogenes was turned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:23
verses.text: He had a wooden dish for drinking; but on one occasion seeing a boy drinking with the hollow of his hand he is related to have dashed the cup to the ground, saying that he did not know nature provided a cup.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:24
verses.text: His virtue and self-restraint were proved even by his death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:25
verses.text: It is said that, now an old man, he was on his way to the Olympic games, which used to be attended by a great concourse of people from all parts of Greece, when he was overtaken by fever and lay down upon the bank by the road-side.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:26
verses.text: And when his friends wished to place him on a beast or in a conveyance, he did not assent, but crossing to the shade of a tree said, "Go your way, I pray you, and see the games: this night will prove me either conquered or conqueror.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:27
verses.text: If I conquer the fever, I shall go to the games: if the fever conquers me, I shall enter the unseen world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:28
verses.text: There through the night he lay gasping for breath and did not, as we are told, so much die as banish the fever by death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 14:29
