verses.text: I have cited the example of only one philosopher, so that our fine, erect, muscular athletes, who hardly make a shadow of a footmark in their swift passage, whose words are in their fists and their reasoning in their heels, who either know nothing of apostolic poverty and the hardness of the cross, or despise it, may at least imitate Gentile moderation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:2
verses.text: So far I have dealt with the arguments and examples of philosophers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:3
verses.text: Now I will pass on to the beginning of the human race, that is, to the sphere which belongs to us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:4
verses.text: I will first point out that Adam received a command in paradise to abstain from one tree though he might eat the other fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:5
verses.text: The blessedness of paradise could not be consecrated without abstinence from food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:6
verses.text: So long as he fasted, he remained in paradise; he ate, and was cast out; he was no sooner cast out than he married a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:7
verses.text: While he fasted in paradise he continued a virgin: when he filled himself with food in the earth, he bound himself with the tie of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:8
verses.text: And yet though cast out he did not immediately receive permission to eat flesh; but only the fruits of trees and the produce of the crops, and herbs and vegetables were given him for food, that even when an exile from paradise he might feed not upon flesh which was not to be found in paradise, but upon grain and fruit like that of paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:9
verses.text: But afterwards whenGod saw that the heart of man from his youth was set on wickedness continually, and that His Spirit could not remain in them because they were flesh, He by the deluge passed sentence on the works of the flesh, and, taking note of the extreme greediness of men,gave them liberty to eat flesh: so that while understanding that all things were lawful for them, they might not greatly desire that which was allowed, lest they should turn a commandment into a cause of transgression.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:10
verses.text: And yet even then, fasting was in part commanded.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:11
verses.text: For, seeing that some animals are called clean, some unclean, and the unclean animals were taken into Noah's ark by pairs, the clean in uneven numbers (and of course the eating of the unclean was forbidden, otherwise the term unclean would be unmeaning), fasting was in part consecrated: restraint in the use of all was taught by the prohibition of some.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:12
verses.text: Why did Esau lose his birthright? Was it not on account of food? and he could not atone with tears for the impatience of his appetite.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:13
verses.text: The people of Israel cast out from Egypt and on their way to the land of promise, the land flowing with milk and honey, longed for the flesh of Egypt, and the melons and garlic, saying: "Would that we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the flesh pots".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:14
verses.text: And again, "Who shall give us flesh to eat? We remember the fish which we did eat in Egypt for nought; the cucumbers, and the melons, and the leeks, and the onions, and the garlic: but now our soul is dried away: we have nought save this manna to look to".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:15
verses.text: They despised angels' food, and sighed for the flesh of Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:16
verses.text: Moses for forty days and forty nights fasted on Mount Sinai, and showed even then that man does not live on bread alone, but on every word of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:17
verses.text: He says to the Lord, "the people is full and maketh idols".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:18
verses.text: Moses with empty stomach received the law written with the finger of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:19
verses.text: The people that ate and drank and rose up to play fashioned a golden calf, and preferred an Egyptian ox to the majesty of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:20
verses.text: The toil of so many days perished through the fulness of a single hour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:21
verses.text: Moses boldly broke the tables: for he knew that drunkards cannot hear the word of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:22
verses.text: The beloved grew thick, waxed fat, and became sleek: he kicked and forsook the Lord which made him, and departed from the God of his salvation".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:23
verses.text: Hence also it is enjoined in the same Book of Deuteronomy: "Beware, lest when thou hast eaten and drunk, and hast built goodly houses, and when thy herds and thy flocks multiply, and thy silver and gold is multiplied, then thine heart be lifted up, and thou forget the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:24
verses.text: In short the people ate and their heart grew thick, lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart: so the people well fed and fat-fleshed could not bear the countenance of Moses who fasted, for, to correctly render the Hebrew, it was furnished with horns through his converse with God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:25
verses.text: And it was not, as some think, to show that there is no difference between virginity and marriage, but to assert his sympathy with severe fasting, that our Lord and Saviour when he was transfigured on the Mount revealed Moses and Elias with Himself in glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:26
verses.text: Although Moses and Elias were properly types of the Law and the Prophets, as is clearly witnessed by the Gospel:"They spake of his departure which he was about to accomplish at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:27
verses.text: For the passion of our Lord is declared not by virginity or marriage, but by the Law and the Prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:28
verses.text: If, however, any persons contentiously maintain that by Moses is signified marriage, by Elias virginity, let me tell them briefly that Moses died and was buried, but Elias was carried off in a chariot of fire and entered on immortality before he approached death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:29
verses.text: But the second writing of the tables could not be effected without fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:30
verses.text: What was lost by drunkenness was regained by abstinence, a proof that by fasting we can return to paradise, whence, though fulness, we have been expelled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:31
verses.text: InExodus we read that the battle was fought against Amalek while Moses prayed, and the whole people fasted until the evening.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:32
verses.text: Joshua, the son of Nun, bade sun and moon stand still, and the victorious army prolonged its fast for more than a day.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:33
verses.text: Saul, as it is written in the first book of Kings, pronounced a curse on him who ate bread before the evening, and until he had avenged himself upon his enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:34
verses.text: So none of his people tasted any food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:35
verses.text: And all they of the land took food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:36
verses.text: And so binding was a solemn fast once it was proclaimed to the Lord, that Jonathan, to whom the victory was due, was taken by lot, andcould not escape the charge of sinning in ignorance, and his father's hand was raised against him, and the prayers of the people scarce availed to save him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:37
verses.text: Elijah after the preparation of a forty days fast saw God on Mount Horeb, and heard from Him the words, "What doest thou here, Elijah?" There is much more familiarity in this than in the "Where art thou, Adam?" of Genesis.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:38
verses.text: The latter was intended to excite the fears of one who had fed and was lost; the former was affectionately addressed to a fasting servant.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:39
verses.text: When the people were assembled in Mizpeh, Samuel proclaimed a fast, and so strengthened them, and thus made them prevail against the enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:40
verses.text: The attack of the Assyrians was repulsed, and the might of Sennacherib utterly crushed, by the tears and sackcloth of King Hezekiah, and by his humbling himself with fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:41
verses.text: So also the city of Nineveh by fasting excited compassion and turned aside the threatening wrath of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:42
verses.text: AndSodom and Gomorrha might have appeased it, had they been willing to repent, and through the aid of fasting gain for themselves tears of repentance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:43
verses.text: Ahab, the most impious of kings, by fasting and wearing sackcloth, succeeded in escaping the sentence of God, and in deferring the overthrow of his house to the days of his posterity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:44
verses.text: Hannah, the wife of Elkanah, by fasting won the gift of a son.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:45
verses.text: At Babylon the magicians came into peril, every interpreter of dreams, soothsayer, and diviner was slain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:46
verses.text: Daniel and the three youths gained a good report by fasting, and although they were fed on pulse, they were fairer and wiser than they who ate the flesh from the king's table.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:47
verses.text: Then it is written that Daniel fasted for three weeks; he ate no pleasant bread; flesh and wine entered not his mouth; he was not anointed with oil; and the angel came to him saying,"Daniel, thou art worthy of compassion".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:48
verses.text: He who in the eyes of God was worthy of compassion, afterwards was an object of terror to the lions in their den.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:49
verses.text: How fair a thing is that which propitiates God, tames lions, terrifies demons! Habakkuk (although we do not find this in the Hebrew Scriptures) was sent to him with the reaper's meal, for by a week's abstinence he had merited so distinguished a server.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:50
verses.text: David, when his son was in danger after his adultery, made confession in ashes and with fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:51
verses.text: He tells us that he ate ashes like bread, and mingled his drink with weeping.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:52
verses.text: And that his knees became weak through fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:53
verses.text: Yet he had certainly heard from Nathan the words,"The Lord also hath put away thy sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:54
verses.text: Samson and Samuel drank neither wine nor strong drink, for they were children of promise, and conceived in abstinence and fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:55
verses.text: Aaron and the other priests when about to enter the temple, refrained from all intoxicating drink for fear they should die.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:56
verses.text: Whence we learn that they die who minister in the Church without sobriety.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:57
verses.text: And hence it is a reproach against Israel:"Ye gave my Nazarites wine to drink".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:58
verses.text: Jonadab, the son of Rechab, commanded his sons to drink no wine for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:59
verses.text: And when Jeremiah offered them wine to drink, and they of their own accord refused it, the Lord spake by the prophet, saying:"Because ye have obeyed the commandment of Jonadab your father, Jonadab the son of Rechab shall not want a man to stand before me for ever".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:60
verses.text: On thethreshold of the Gospel appears Anna, the daughter of Phanuel, the wife of one husband, and a woman who was always fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:61
verses.text: Long-continued chastity and persistent fasting welcomed a Virgin Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:62
verses.text: His forerunner and herald, John, fed on locusts and wild honey, not on flesh; and the hermits of the desert and the monks in their cells, at first used the same sustenance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:63
verses.text: But the Lord Himself consecrated His baptism by a forty days' fast, and He taught us that the more violent devilscannot be overcome, except by prayer and fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:64
verses.text: Cornelius the centurion was found worthy through alms-giving and frequent fasts to receive the gift of the Holy Spirit before baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:65
verses.text: The Apostle Paul, after speaking of hunger and thirst, and his other labours, perils from robbers, shipwrecks, loneliness, enumerates frequent fasts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:66
verses.text: And headvises his disciple Timothy, who had a weak stomach, and was subject to many infirmities, to drink wine in moderation: "Drink no longer water," he says.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:67
verses.text: The fact that he bids him no longer drink water shows that he had previously drunk water.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 15:68
verses.text: The apostle would not have allowed this had not frequent infirmities and bodily pain demanded the concession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:2
verses.text: The Apostle does indeed blame those who forbade marriage, and commanded to abstain from food, which God created for use with thanksgiving.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:3
verses.text: But he has in view Marcion, and Tatian, and other heretics, who inculcate perpetual abstinence, to destroy, and express their hatred and contempt for, the works of the Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:4
verses.text: But we praise every creature of God, and yet prefer leanness to corpulence, abstinence to luxury, fasting to fulness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:5
verses.text: He that laboureth laboureth for himself, and he is eager to his own destruction".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:6
verses.text: And, "From the days of John the Baptist (who fasted and was a virgin) until now the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and men of violence take it by force".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:7
verses.text: For we are afraid lest at the coming of the eternal judge we be caught, as in the days of the flood, and at the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrha, eating and drinking, and marrying, and giving in marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:8
verses.text: For both the flood and the fire from heaven found fulness as well as marriage ready for destruction.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:9
verses.text: Nor need we wonder if the Apostle commands that everything sold in the market be bought and eaten, since with idolaters, and with those who still ate in the temples of the idols meats offered to idols as such, it passed for the highest abstinence to abstain only from food eaten by the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:10
verses.text: And if he says to the Romans:"Let not him that eateth set at nought him that eateth not: and let not him that eateth not judge him that eateth," he does not make fasting and fulness of equal merit, but he is speaking against those believers in Christ who were still judaizing: and he warns Gentile believers, not to offend those by their food who were still too weak in faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:11
verses.text: In brief this is clear enough in the sequel:"I know and am persuaded in the Lord Jesus, that nothing is unclean of itself: save that to him who accounteth anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:12
verses.text: For if because of meat thy brother is grieved, thou walkest no longer in love.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:13
verses.text: Destroy not with thy meat him for whom Christ died.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:14
verses.text: Let not then your good be evil spoken of: for the Kingdom of God is not eating and drinking".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:15
verses.text: And that no one may suppose he is referring to fasting and not to Jewish superstition, he immediately explains, "One man hath faith to eat all things: but he that is weak eateth herbs".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:16
verses.text: And again, "One man esteemeth one day above another: another esteemeth every day alike.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:17
verses.text: Let each man be fully assured in his own mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:18
verses.text: He that regardeth the day, regardeth it unto the Lord: and he that eateth, eateth unto the Lord, for he giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, unto the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:19
verses.text: For they who were still weak in faith and thought some meats clean, some unclean: and supposed there was a difference between one day and another, for example, that the Sabbath, and the New Moons, and the Feast of Tabernacles were holier than other days, were commanded to eat herbs which are indifferently partaken of by all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 16:20
verses.text: But such as were of stronger faith believed all meats and all days to be alike.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:2
verses.text: My opponent has dared to maintain that our Lord was called by the Pharisees a wine-bibber and a glutton: and from the fact of His going to marriage feasts and from His not despising the banquets of sinners, I am to infer His wishes respecting ourselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:3
verses.text: That Lord, so you suppose, is a glutton who fasted forty days to hallow Christian fasting;who calls them blessed that hunger and thirst;who says that He has food, not that which the disciples surmised, but such as would not perish for ever;who forbids us to think of the morrow; who, though He is said to have hungered and thirsted, and to have gone frequently to various meals, except in celebrating the mystery whereby He represented His passion, orin proving the reality of His body is nowhere described as ministering to His appetite;who tells of purple-clad Dives in hell for his feasting, and says that poor Lazarus for his abstinence was in Abraham's bosom; who, when we fast,bids us anoint our head and wash our face, that we fast not to gain glory from men, but praise from the Lord; who did indeedafter His resurrection eat part of a broiled fish and of a honey-comb, not to allay hunger and to gratify His palate, but to show the reality of His own body.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:4
verses.text: For whenever He raised anyone from the dead Heordered that food should be given him to eat, lest the resurrection should be thought a delusion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:5
verses.text: And this is why Lazarus after his resurrection isdescribed as being at the feast with our Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:6
verses.text: We do not deny that fish and other kinds of flesh, if we choose, may be taken as food; but as we prefer virginity to marriage, so do we esteem fasting and spirituality above meats and full-bloodedness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:7
verses.text: And if Peterbefore dinner went to the supper chamber at the sixth hour, a chance fit of hunger does not prejudice fasting.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:8
verses.text: For, if this were so, because our Lord at the sixth hour sat weary on the well of Samaria and wished to drink, all must of necessity, whether they so desire or not, drink at that time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:9
verses.text: Possibly it was the Sabbath, or the Lord's day, and he hungered at the sixth hour after two or three days' fasting; for I could never believe that the Apostle, if he had eaten a dinner only one day previous and had been blown out with a great meal, would have been hungry by noon next day.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:10
verses.text: But if he did dine the day previous, and was hungry next day before luncheon, I do not think that a man who was so soon hungry ate until he was satisfied.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:11
verses.text: Again, God by the mouth of Isaiah says what fast He did not choose:"In the day of your fast ye find pleasure, and afflict the lowly: ye fast for strife and debate, and to smite with the fist of wickedness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:12
verses.text: It is not such a fast that I have chosen, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:13
verses.text: What kind He has chosen He thus teaches: "Deal thy bread to the hungry, and bring the houseless poor into thy house.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:14
verses.text: When thou seest the naked cover him, and hide not thyself from thine own flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:15
verses.text: He did not therefore reject fasting, but showed what He would have it to be: for that bodily hunger is not pleasing to God which is made null and void by strife, and plunder, and lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:16
verses.text: If God does not desire fasting, how is it that inLeviticus He commands the whole people in the seventh month, on the tenth day of the month, to fast until the evening, and threatens that he who does not afflict his soul shall die and be cut off from his people? How is it that thegraves of lust where the people fell in their devotion to flesh remain even to this day in the wilderness? Do we not read that the stupid people gorged themselves with quails until the wrath of God came upon them? Why was the man of God at whose prophecy the hand of King Jeroboam withered, and who ate contrary to the command of God,immediately smitten? Strange that the lion which left the ass safe and sound should not spare the prophet just risen from his meal! He who, while he was fasting, had wrought miracles, no sooner ate a meal than he paid the penalty for the gratification.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:17
verses.text: Joel also cries aloud:"Sanctify a fast, proclaim a time of healing," that it might appear that a fast is sanctified by other works, and that a holy fast avails for the cure of sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:18
verses.text: Moreover, just as true virginity is not prejudiced by the counterfeit professions of the virgins of the devil, so neither is true fasting by the periodic fast and perpetual abstinence from certain kinds of food on the part of the worshippers of Isis and Cybele, particularly when a fast from bread is made up for by feasting on flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 17:19
verses.text: And just as the signs of Moses were imitated by the signs of the Egyptians which were in reality no signs at all, for the rod of Moses swallowed up the rods of the magicians: so when the devil tries to be the rival of God this does not prove that our religion is superstitious, but that we are negligent, since we refuse to do what even men of the world see clearly to be good.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:2
verses.text: His fourth and last contention is that there are two classes, the sheep and the goats, the just and the unjust: that the just stand on the right hand, the other on the left: and that to the just the words are spoken:"Come, ye blessed of my Father, and inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:3
verses.text: But that sinners are thus addressed:"Depart from me, ye cursed, into the eternal fire which is prepared for the devil and his angels".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:4
verses.text: That a good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, nor an evil tree good fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:5
verses.text: Hence it is that the Saviour says to the Jews:"Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father it is your will to do".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:6
verses.text: He quotes the parable of the ten virgins, the wise and the foolish, and shows that the five who had no oil remained outside, but that the other five who had gotten for themselves the light of good works went into the marriage with the bridegroom.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:7
verses.text: He goes back to the flood, and tells us that they who were righteous like Noah were saved, but that the sinners perished all together.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:8
verses.text: We are informed that among the men of Sodom and Gomorrha no difference is made except between the two classes of the good and the bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:9
verses.text: The righteous are delivered, the sinners are consumed by the same fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:10
verses.text: There is one salvation for those who are released, one destruction for those who stay behind.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:11
verses.text: Lot's wife is a clear warning that we must not deviate a hair's breadth from right.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:12
verses.text: If, however, he says, you object and ask me why the righteous toils in time of peace, or in the midst of persecution, if he is to gain nothing nor have a greater reward, I would assert that he does this, not that he may gain a further reward but that he may not lose what he has already received.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:13
verses.text: In Egypt also the ten plagues fell with equal violence upon all that sinned, and the same darkness hung over master and slave, noble and ignoble, the king and the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:14
verses.text: Again at the Red Sea the righteous all passed over, the sinners were all overwhelmed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:15
verses.text: Six hundred thousand men, besides those who were unfit for war through age or sex, all alike fell in the desert, and two who were alike in righteousness are alike delivered.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:16
verses.text: For forty years all Israel toiled and died alike.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:17
verses.text: As regards food, an homer of manna was the measure for all ages: the clothes of all alike did not wear out: the hair of all alike did not grow, nor the beard increase: the shoes of all lasted the same time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:18
verses.text: Their feet grew not hard: the food in the mouths of all had the same taste.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:19
verses.text: They went on their way to one resting place with equal toil and equal reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:20
verses.text: All Hebrews had the same Passover, the same Feast of Tabernacles, the same Sabbath, the same New Moons.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 18:21
verses.text: In the seventh, the Sabbatical Year, all prisoners were released without distinction of persons, and in the year of Jubilee all debts were forgiven to all debtors, and he who had sold land returned to the inheritance of his fathers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:2
verses.text: Then, again, as regards the parable of the sower in the Gospel, we read that the good ground brought forth fruit, some a hundred fold, some sixty fold, and some thirty fold; and, on the other hand, that the bad ground admitted of three degrees of sterility: but Jovinianus makes only two classes, the good soil and the bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:3
verses.text: And as in one Gospel our Lord promises the Apostles a hundred fold, in another seven fold, for leaving children and wives, and in the world to come life eternal; and the seven and the hundred mean the same thing: so, too, in the passage before us, the numbers describing the fertility of the soil need not create any difficulty, particularly when the Evangelist Mark gives the inverse order, thirty, sixty, and a hundred.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:4
verses.text: The Lord says, "He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood abideth in me, and I in him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:5
verses.text: As, then, there are not varying degrees of Christ's presence in us, so neither are there degrees of our abiding in Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:6
verses.text: Every one that loveth me will keep my word: and my Father will love him, and we will come unto him, and make our abode with him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:7
verses.text: He that is righteous, loves Christ: and if a man thus loves, the Father and the Son come to him, and make their abode with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:8
verses.text: Now I suppose that when the guest is such as this the host cannot possibly lack anything.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:9
verses.text: And if our Lord says, "In my Father's house are many mansions," His meaning is not that there are different mansions in the kingdom of heaven, but He indicates the number of Churches in the whole world, for though the Church be seven-fold she is but one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:10
verses.text: "I go," He says, "to prepare a place for you," not places.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:11
verses.text: If this promise is peculiar to the twelve apostles, then Paul is shut out from that place, and the chosen vessel will be thought superfluous and unworthy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:12
verses.text: John and James, because they asked more than the others, did not obtain it; and yet their dignity is not diminished, because they were equal to the rest of the apostles".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:13
verses.text: Know ye not that your bodies are a temple of the Holy Ghost?" A temple, He says, not temples, in order to show that God dwells in all alike".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:14
verses.text: Neither for these only do I pray, but for them also that believe on me through their word; as thou, Father, in me, and I in thee, are one, so they may be all one in us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:15
verses.text: And the glory which thou hast given me I have given unto them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:16
verses.text: I have loved them, as thou hast loved me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:17
verses.text: And as we are Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, one God, so may they be one people in themselves, that is, like dear children, partakers of the divine nature".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:18
verses.text: Call the Church what you will, bride, sister, mother, her assembly is but one and never lacks husband, brother, or son.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:19
verses.text: Her faith is one, and she is not defiled by variety of doctrine, nor divided by heresies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:20
verses.text: She continues a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 19:21
verses.text: Whithersoever the Lamb goeth, she follows Him: she alone knows the Song of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:2
verses.text: "If you tell me," says he, "that one star differeth from another star in glory, I reply, that one star does differ from another star; that is, spiritual persons differ from carnal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:3
verses.text: We love all the members alike, and do not prefer the eye to the finger, nor the finger to the ear: but the loss of any one is attended by the sorrow of all the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:4
verses.text: We all alike come into this world, and we all alike depart from it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:5
verses.text: There is one Adam of the earth, and another from heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:6
verses.text: The earthly Adam is on the left hand, and will perish: the heavenly Adam is on the right hand, and will be saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:7
verses.text: He who says to his brother, 'thou fool,' and 'raca,' will be in danger of Gehenna.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:8
verses.text: And the murderer and the adulterer will likewise be sent into Gehenna.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:9
verses.text: In times of persecution some are burnt, some strangled, some beheaded, some flee, or die within the walls of a prison: the struggle varies in kind, but the victors' crown is one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:10
verses.text: No difference was made between the son who had never left his father, and his brother who was welcomed as a returning penitent.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 20:11
verses.text: To the labourers of the first hour, the third, the sixth, the ninth, and the eleventh, the same reward of a penny was given, and what may perhaps seem still more strange to you, the first to receive the reward were they who had toiled least in the vineyard".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:2
verses.text: Who is there even of God's elect that would not be disturbed at these and similar passages of Holy Scripture which our crafty opponent, with a perverse ingenuity, twists to the support of his own views? The Apostle John says that many Antichrists had come, and to make no difference between John himself and the lowest penitent is the preaching of a real Antichrist.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:3
verses.text: At the same time, I am amazed at the portentous forms which Jovinianus, as slippery as a snake and like another Proteus, so rapidly assumes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:4
verses.text: In sexual intercourse and full feeding he is an Epicurean; in the distribution of rewards and punishments he all at once becomes a Stoic, He exchanges Jerusalem forCitium, Judaea for Cyprus, Christ for Zeno.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:5
verses.text: If we may not depart a hair's breadth from virtue, and all sins are equal, and a man who in a fit of hunger steals a piece of bread is no less guilty than he who slays a man: you must, in your turn, be held guilty of the greatest crimes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:6
verses.text: The case is different if you say that you have no sin, not even the least, and if, although all apostles and prophets and all the saints (as I have maintained in dealing withhis second proposition) bewail their sinfulness, you alone boast of your righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:7
verses.text: But a minute ago you were barefooted: now you not only wear shoes, but decorated ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:8
verses.text: Just now you wore a rough coat and a dirty shirt, you were grimy, and haggard, and your hand was horny with toil: now you are clad in linen and silks, and strut like an exquisite in the fashions of the Atrebates and the Laodiceans.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:9
verses.text: Your cheeks are ruddy, your skin sleek, your hair smoothed down in front and behind, your belly protrudes, your shoulders are little mountains, your neck full and so loaded with fat that the half-smothered words can scarce make their escape.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:10
verses.text: Surely in such extremes of dress and mode of life there must be sin on the one side or the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:11
verses.text: I will not assert that the sin lies in the food or clothing, but that such fickleness and changing for the worse is almost censurable in itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:12
verses.text: And what we censure, is far removed from virtue; and what is far from virtue becomes the property of vice; and what is proved to be vicious is one with sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:13
verses.text: Now sin, according to you, is placed on the left hand, and corresponds to the goats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 21:14
verses.text: You must, therefore, return to your old habits if you are to be a sheep on the right hand; or, if you perversely repent of your former views and change them for others, whether you like it or not, and although you shave off your beard, you will be reckoned among the goats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:2
verses.text: But what is the good of calling aone-eyed man Old One-eye, and of showing the inconsistency of an assailant, when we have to refute a whole series of statements? That the sheep and the goats on the right hand and on the left are the two classes of the righteous and the wicked, I do not deny.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:3
verses.text: That a good tree does not bring forth evil fruit, nor an evil one good fruit, no one doubts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:4
verses.text: The ten virgins also, wise and foolish, we divide into good and bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:5
verses.text: We are not ignorant that at the deluge the righteous were delivered, and sinners overwhelmed with the waters.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:6
verses.text: That at Sodom and Gomorrha the just man was rescued, while the sinners were consumed by fire, is clear to everyone.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:7
verses.text: We are also aware that Egypt was stricken with the ten plagues, and that Israel was saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:8
verses.text: Even little children in our schools sing how the righteous passed through the Red Sea, and Pharaoh with his host was drowned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:9
verses.text: That six hundred thousand fell in the desert because they were unbelieving, and that two only entered the land of promise, is taught by Scripture; and so is the rest of your description of the two classes, good and bad, down to the labourers in the vineyard.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:10
verses.text: But what are we to think of your assertion, that because there is a division into good and bad, the good, or the bad it may be, are not distinguished one from another, and that it makes no difference whether one is a ram in the flock or a poor little sheep? whether the sheep have the first or the second fleece? whether the flock is diseased and covered with the scab, or full of life and vigour? especially when by the authoritative utterances of His own prophet Ezekiel God clearly points out the difference between flock and flock of His rational sheep, saying, "Behold I judge between cattle and cattle, and between the rams and the he-goats, and between the fat cattle and the lean.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:11
verses.text: Because ye have thrust with side and with shoulder, and pushed all the diseased with your horns, until they were scattered abroad".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:12
verses.text: And that we might know what the cattle were, He immediately added:"Ye my flock, the flock of my pasture, are men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:13
verses.text: Will Paul and that penitent who had lain with his father's wife be on an equality, because the latter repented and was received into the Church: and shall the offender because he is with him on the right hand shine with the same glory as the Apostle? How is it then that tares and wheat grow side by side in the same field until the harvest, that is the end of the world? What is the significance of good and bad fish being contained in the Gospel net? Why, in Noah's ark, the type of the Church, are there different animals with different abodes according to their rank? Why standeth the queen upon the Lord's right hand, in raiment of wrought gold, in a vesture of gold? Why had Joseph, representing Christ, a coat of many colours? Why does the Apostle say to the Romans:"According as God had dealt to each man a measure of faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:14
verses.text: For even as we have many members in one body, and all the members have not the same office: so we, who are many, are one body in Christ, and severally members one of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:15
verses.text: And having gifts differing according to the grace that was given to us, whether prophecy, let us prophesy according to the proportion of our faith; or ministry, let us give ourselves to our ministry; or he that teacheth, to his teaching; or he that exhorteth, to his exhorting: he that giveth, let him do it with liberality; he that ruleth, with diligence," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:16
verses.text: And elsewhere:"One man esteemeth one day above another: another esteemeth every day alike.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:17
verses.text: Let every man be fully persuaded in his own mind".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:18
verses.text: To the Corinthians he says:"I have planted, Apollos watered: but God gave the increase.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:19
verses.text: So then, neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth: but God that giveth the increase.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:20
verses.text: Now he that planteth and he that watereth are one: and every man shall receive his own reward according to his own labour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:21
verses.text: For we are labourers together with God, ye are God's husbandry, ye are God's building".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:22
verses.text: And again elsewhere:"According to the grace of God which is given unto me, as a wise master-builder I laid a foundation, and another buildeth thereon.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:23
verses.text: But let each man take heed how he buildeth thereupon.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:24
verses.text: For other foundation can no man lay, than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:25
verses.text: But if any man buildeth on the foundation, gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble: each man's work shall be made manifest: for the day shall reveal it, because it is revealed in fire: and the fire itself shall prove each man's work of what sort it is.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:26
verses.text: If any man's work shall abide which he built thereon, he shall receive a reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:27
verses.text: If any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as through fire".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:28
verses.text: If the man whose work is burnt and is to suffer the loss of his labour, while he himself is saved, yet not without proof of fire: it follows that if a man's work remains which he has built upon the foundation, he will be saved without probation by fire, and consequently a difference is established between one degree of salvation and another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:29
verses.text: Again in another place he says:"Let a man so account of us, as of ministers of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:30
verses.text: Here, moreover, it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:31
verses.text: Would you be assured that between one steward and another there is a great difference (I am not speaking of bad and good, but of the good themselves who stand on the right hand)? then listen to the sequel:"Know ye not that they which minister about the sacrifices, eat of the sacrifices, and they which wait upon the altar have their portion with the altar? Even so did the Lord ordain that they which proclaim the gospel should live of the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:32
verses.text: But I have used none of these things: and I wrote not these things that it may be so done in my case: for it were good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my glorying void.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:33
verses.text: For if I preach the gospel, I have nothing to glory of; for necessity is laid upon me; for woe is unto me if I preach not the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:34
verses.text: For if I do this of mine own will, I have a reward: but if not of mine own will, I have a steward-ship intrusted to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:35
verses.text: What then is my reward? That, when I preach the gospel, I may make the gospel without charge, so as not to use to the full my right in the gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:36
verses.text: For though I was free from all men, I brought myself under bondage to all, that I might gain the more".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:37
verses.text: You surely cannot say that men commit sin by living by the Gospel, and partaking of the sacrifices.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:38
verses.text: Of course not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:39
verses.text: The Lord himself made the rule that they who preach the Gospel, should live by the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 22:40
verses.text: But an Apostle who does not abuse this freedom, but labours with his hands that he may not be a burden to anyone, and toils night and day and ministers to his companions of course does this, that for his greater toil he may receive a greater reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:2
verses.text: Let us hasten to what remains".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:3
verses.text: There are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:4
verses.text: And there are diversities of ministrations, and the same Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:5
verses.text: And there are diversities of operations, but the same God who worketh all things in all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:6
verses.text: But to each one is given the manifestation of the Spirit to profit withal".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:7
verses.text: And again: "As the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of the body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:8
verses.text: But he precludes you from saying that the different members of the one body have the same rank; for he immediately describes the orders of the Church, and says:"And God hath set some in the Church, first, apostles; secondly, prophets; thirdly, teachers; then miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, divers kinds of tongues.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:9
verses.text: Are all apostles? are all prophets? are all teachers? are all workers of miracles? have all gifts of healings? do all speak with tongues? do all interpret? But desire earnestly the greater gifts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:10
verses.text: And a still more excellent way shew I unto you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:11
verses.text: And after discoursing more in detail of the graces of charity, he added: "Whether there be prophecies, they shall be done away; whether there be tongues, they shall cease; whether there be knowledge, it shall be done away.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:12
verses.text: For we know in part, and we prophesy in part: but when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:13
verses.text: And afterwards we read: "But now abideth faith, hope, love, these three; and the greatest of these is love.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:14
verses.text: Follow after love; yet desire earnestly spiritual gifts, but rather that ye may prophesy".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:15
verses.text: And again: "I would have you all speak with tongues, but rather that ye should prophesy: and greater is he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:16
verses.text: And again: "I thank God, I speak with tongues more than you all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:17
verses.text: Where there are different gifts, and one man is greater, another less, and all are called spiritual, they are all certainly sheep, and they stand on the right hand; but there is a difference between one sheep and another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:18
verses.text: It is humility that leads the Apostle Paul to say:"I am the least of the apostles, that am not meet to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:19
verses.text: But by the grace of God I am what I am: and his grace which was bestowed upon me was not found vain: but I laboured more abundantly than they all: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:20
verses.text: But the very fact of his thus humbling himself shows the possibility of there being apostles of higher or lower rank, and God is not unjust that He will forget the work of him who is called the chosen vessel of election, and who laboured more abundantly than they all, or assign equal rewards to unequal deserts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:21
verses.text: Afterwards we read, "As in Adam all die, so also in Christ shall all be now alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:22
verses.text: But each in his own order".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:23
verses.text: If each is to rise in his own order, it follows that those who rise are of different degrees of merit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:24
verses.text: All flesh is not the same flesh; but there is one flesh of men, and another flesh of beasts, and another flesh of birds, and another of fishes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:25
verses.text: There are also celestial bodies, and bodies terrestrial: but the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the terrestrial is another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:26
verses.text: There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for one star differeth from another star in glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:27
verses.text: So also is the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:28
verses.text: Like a learned commentator, you have explained this passage by saying that the spiritual differ from the carnal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:29
verses.text: It follows that in heaven there will be both spiritual and carnal persons, and not only will the sheep climb thither, but your goats also.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:30
verses.text: "One star," he says, "differeth from another star in glory": this is not the distinction of sheep and goat, but of sheep and sheep, star and star.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:31
verses.text: Lastly, he says, "there is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:32
verses.text: But for this, you might maintain that the phrase one star from another star covers the whole human race; but he introduces the sun and moon, and you cannot possibly reckon them among the goats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:33
verses.text: "So," says he, "is also the resurrection of the dead"—the just will shine with the brightness of the sun, and those of the next rank will glow with the splendour of the moon, so that one will be a Lucifer, another an Arcturus, a third an Orion, another Mazzaroth, or some other of the stars whose names are hollowed in the book of Job".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:34
verses.text: For we all," he says, "must be made manifest before the judgment-seat of Christ; that each one may receive the things done in the body, according to what he hath done, whether it be good or bad".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:35
verses.text: And you cannot say that the mode of our manifestation before the judgment-seat of Christ is such that the good receive good things, the bad evil things; for he teaches us in the same epistle that he who soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly, and he that soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:36
verses.text: Surely he who sows more and he who sows less are both on the right side.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:37
verses.text: And although they belong to the same class, that of the sower, yet they differ in respect of measure and number.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:38
verses.text: The same Paul, writing to the Ephesians, says: "to the intent that now unto the principalities and the powers in the heavenly places might be made known through the church the manifold wisdom of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:39
verses.text: You observe that it is a varied and manifold wisdom of God which is spoken of as existing in the different ranks of the church.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 23:40
verses.text: And in the same epistle we read,"Unto each one of us was the grace given according to the measure of the grace of Christ": not that Christ's measure varies, but only that so much of His grace is poured out as we can receive.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:2
verses.text: In vain, therefore, do you multiply instances of sheep and goats, of the five wise and five foolish virgins, of Egyptians and Israelites, and so forth, because retribution is not in the present, but will be in the future.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:3
verses.text: Hence we find that the day of judgment is promised at the end of all things, because the judgment is not now.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:4
verses.text: For it would be absurd to call the last day the day of judgment, if God were judging at the present time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:5
verses.text: Now we sail the ship, wrestle, and fight, that at last we may reach the haven, be crowned, and triumph.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:6
verses.text: But you, with no less adroitness than perversity, make the life of this world illustrate that of the world to come, although we know full well that here unrighteousness prevails, there, righteousness:"until we go into the sanctuary of God, and understand the end of those men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:7
verses.text: The saint does not die one way, the sinner another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:8
verses.text: Those who sail the same sea have the same calm and storm.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:9
verses.text: A violent death is not one thing to the robber, another to the martyr.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:10
verses.text: Children are not born one way of adultery and prostitution, in another of pure marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:11
verses.text: Certainly our Lord and the robbers incurred the same penalty of crucifixion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:12
verses.text: If the judgment of this world and of that which is to come be the same, it follows that they who were here crucified side by side, will also be esteemed of equal rank hereafter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:13
verses.text: Paul and they who bound him, sailed together, endured the same storm, escaped together to the shore when the ship was broken with the waves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:14
verses.text: You cannot deny that the prisoner and the keepers were of unequal merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:15
verses.text: And what were the circumstances of that same shipwreck of the Apostle and the soldiers? The Apostle Paul afterwards related a vision, and said that they who were with him in the ship had been given to him by the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:16
verses.text: Are we to suppose that he to whom they were given, and they who were given to him, were of one degree of merit? Ten righteous men can save a sinful city.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:17
verses.text: Lot together with his daughters was delivered from the fire: his sons-in-law would also have been saved, had they been willing to leave the city.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:18
verses.text: Now there was surely a great difference between Lot and his sons-in-law.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:19
verses.text: One city out of the five,Zoar, was saved, and a place which lay under the same sentence as Sodom, Gomorrha, Admah, and Zeboiim, was preserved by the prayers of a holy man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:20
verses.text: Lot and Zoar were of different merit, but both of them escaped the fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:21
verses.text: The robbers who in the absence of David had laid waste Ziklag, and made a prey of the wives and children of the inhabitants were slain on the third day in the plain, but forty men mounted on camels fled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:22
verses.text: Will you maintain that there was some difference between those who were slain and those who made good their escape? We read in theGospel that the tower of Siloam fell upon eighteen men who perished in the ruins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:23
verses.text: Certainly our Saviour did not regard them as the only sinners: but they were punished to terrify the rest: it was like scourging a pestilent fellow to teach fools wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 24:24
verses.text: If all sinners are punished alike, it is unjust for one to be slain while another is admonished by his comrade's death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:2
verses.text: You raise the objection that all Israelites had the same measure of manna, an homer, and were alike in respect of dress, and hair, and beard, and shoes; as though we did not all alike partake of the body of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:3
verses.text: In the Christian mysteries there is one means of sanctification for the master and the servant, the noble and the low-born, for the king and his soldiers, and yet, that which is one varies according to the merits of those who receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:4
verses.text: Whosoever shall eat or drink unworthily shall be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:5
verses.text: Does it follow that because Judas drank of the same cup as the rest of the apostles, that he and they are of equal merit? But suppose that we do not choose to receive the sacrament, at all events we all have the same life, breathe the same air, have the same blood in our veins, are fed on the same food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:6
verses.text: Moreover, if our viands are improved by culinary skill and are made more palatable for the consumer, food of this kind does not satisfy nature, but tickles the appetite.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:7
verses.text: We are all alike subject to hunger, all alike suffer with cold: we alike are shrivelled with the frost, or melted with the broiling heat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:8
verses.text: The sun and the moon, and all the company of the stars, the showers, the whole world run their course for us all alike, and, as the Gospel tells us, the same refreshing rain falls upon all, good and bad, just and unjust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:9
verses.text: If the present is a picture of the future, then the Sun of Righteousness will rise upon sinners as well as upon the righteous, upon the wicked and the holy, upon the heathen as well as upon Jews and Christians, though the Scripture says, "Unto you that fear the Lord shall the Sun of Righteousness arise".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:10
verses.text: If He will rise to those that fear, He will set to the despisers and the false prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:11
verses.text: The sheep which stand on the right hand will be brought into the kingdom of heaven, the goats will be thrust down to hell.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:12
verses.text: The parable does not contrast the sheep one with another, or on the other hand the goats, but merely makes a difference between sheep and goats.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:13
verses.text: The whole truth is not taught in a single passage: we must always bear in mind the exact point of an illustration.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:14
verses.text: For instance, the ten virgins are not examples of the whole human race, but of the careful and the slothful: the former are ever anticipating the advent of our Lord, the latter abandon themselves to idle slumber without a thought of future judgment.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:15
verses.text: And so at the end of the parable it is said, "Watch, for ye know not the day, nor the hour".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:16
verses.text: If at the deluge Noah was delivered, and the whole world perished, all men were flesh, and therefore were destroyed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:17
verses.text: You must either say that the sons of Noah and Noah for whose sake they were delivered were of unequal merit, or you must place the accursed Ham in the same rank as his father because he was delivered with him from the flood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:18
verses.text: At the passion of Christ all wavered, all were unprofitable together: there was none that did good, no not one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:19
verses.text: Will you therefore dare to say that Peter and the rest of the Apostles who fled denied the Saviour in the same sense as Caiaphas and the Pharisees and the people who cried out, "Crucify him, crucify him"? And, to say no more about the Apostles, do you think Annas and Caiaphas, and Judas the traitor guilty of no greater crime than Pilate who was compelled against his will to give sentence against our Lord? The guilt of Judas is proportioned to his former merit, and the greater the guilt, the greater the penalty too".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:20
verses.text: For the mighty shall mightily suffer torment".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:21
verses.text: An evil tree does not bear good fruit, nor a good tree evil fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:22
verses.text: If this be so, tell me how it was that Paul though he was an evil tree and persecuted the Church of Christ, afterwards bore good fruit? And Judas, though he was a good tree and wrought miracles like the other Apostles, afterwards turned traitor and brought forth evil fruit? The truth is that a good tree does not bear evil fruit, nor an evil tree good fruit, so long as they continue in their goodness, or badness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:23
verses.text: And if we read that every Hebrew keeps the same Passover, and that inthe seventh year every prisoner is set free, and that at Jubilee, that is the fiftieth year,every possession returns to its owner, all this refers not to the present, but to the future; for being in bondage during the six days of this world, on the seventh day, the true and eternal Sabbath, we shall be free, at any rate if we wish to be free while still in bondage in the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 25:24
verses.text: If, however, we do not desire it, our ear will be bored in token of our disobedience, and together with our wives and children, whom we preferred to liberty, that is, with the flesh and its works, we shall be in perpetual slavery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:2
verses.text: As for the parable of the sower which makes both good and bad ground bear a triple crop, and the passage from the apostle in which upon Christ as the foundation one man builds gold, silver, costly stones, another wood, hay, stubble, the meaning is perfectly clear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:3
verses.text: We know that in a great house there are different vessels, and to wish to contradict so plain a truth would be sheer impudence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:4
verses.text: Yet that Jovinianus may not triumph in a lie and quote the instance of the apostles by way of discrediting the hundred fold, sixty fold, and thirty fold, let me inform him that in Matthew and Mark a hundred fold is promised to the apostles who had left all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:5
verses.text: And I would tell him further, that in the Gospel of Luke we find much more, that is πολύ πλείονα, and that there is absolutely no instance in the Gospels of a hundred standing for seven; and that he is convicted either of forgery, or of ignorance; and that our cause is not prejudiced by the fact that in one Gospel the enumeration begins at a hundred, in another at thirty, since it is a rule with all Scripture, and especially with the older writings, to put the lowest number first and so ascend by degrees to the higher.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:6
verses.text: For instance, suppose one to say that so-and-so lived five and seventy and a hundred years, it does not follow that five and seventy are more than a hundred because they were first mentioned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:7
verses.text: If you do not on the side of good admit the difference between a hundred, sixty, and thirty, neither will you do so on the side of evil, and the seed which fell by the wayside, upon the rock, and among thorns, will be equally faulty.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:8
verses.text: But if the former three, or the latter three, on the side of good, or on the side of evil respectively, are one and the same, it was foolish instead of speaking of two things to enumerate six kinds, and all the more because according to the account of the parable in Matthew, Mark, and Luke, the Saviour always added: "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 26:9
verses.text: Where there is no deep inner meaning, it is useless to draw our attention to the mystic sense.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:2
verses.text: You give it as your opinion that, since the Father and the Son make their abode with the faithful, and since Christ is their guest, nothing is lacking.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:3
verses.text: I suppose, however, that Christ's abiding with the Corinthians was one thing, with the Ephesians another: it was one thing, I say, for Him to abide with those whom Paul blamed for many sins, another for Him to dwell with those to whom the apostle revealed mysteries hidden from the beginning of the world; one thing for Him to be in Titus and Timothy, another in Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:4
verses.text: Certainly amongst them that have been born of women, there has not arisen a greater than John the Baptist.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:5
verses.text: But the term greater implies others who are less.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:6
verses.text: And "he who is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:7
verses.text: You see then that in heaven one is greatest and another is least, and that among the angels and the invisible creation there is a manifold and infinite diversity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:8
verses.text: Why do the apostles say:"Lord, increase our faith," if there is one measure for all? And why did our Lord rebuke His disciple, saying:"O thou of little faith, wherefore didst thou doubt?" In Jeremiah also we read concerning the future kingdom:"Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and with the house of Judah not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:9
verses.text: And so on after:"I will put my law in their inward parts, and in their heart will I write it; and I will be their God and they shall be my people: and they shall teach no more every man his neighbour, and every man his brother, saying, Know the Lord: for they shall all know me, from the least of them unto the greatest of them".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:10
verses.text: The context of this passage clearly shows that the prophet is describing the future kingdom, and how can there possibly be in it a least or greatest, if all are to be equal? The secret is disclosed in the Gospel:"Whosoever shall do and teach, he shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven: but whosoever shall teach, and not do, shall be least".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:11
verses.text: The Saviour taught us at a feast to take the lowest place, lest, when one greater than us came, we should be thrust with disgrace from the higher place.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:12
verses.text: If we cannot fall, but only raise ourselves by penitence, what is the meaning of the ladder at Bethel, on which the angels come from heaven to earth and descend as well as ascend? Surely while on that ladder they are reckoned among the sheep and stand on the right hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 27:13
verses.text: There are angels who descend from heaven; but Jovinianus is sure that they retain their inheritance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:2
verses.text: But when Jovinianus supposes that the many mansions in our Father's house are churches scattered throughout the world, who can refrain from laughing; since Scripture plainly teaches in John's Gospel that our Lord was discoursing not of the number of the churches, but of the heavenly mansions, and the eternal tabernacles for which the prophet longed?"In my Father's house," He says, "are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you; for I go to prepare a place for you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:3
verses.text: And if I go and prepare a place for you I will come again, and will receive you unto myself, that where I am, there ye may be also".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:4
verses.text: The place and the mansions which Christ says He would prepare for the apostles are of course in the Father's house, that is, in the kingdom of heaven, not on earth, where for the present He was leading the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:5
verses.text: And at the same time regard must be had to the sense of Scripture: "I might tell you," He says, "that I go to prepare a place for you, if there were not many mansions in my Father's house, that is to say, if each individual did not prepare for himself a mansion through his own works rather than receive it through the bounty of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:6
verses.text: The preparation is therefore not mine, but yours".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:7
verses.text: This view is supported by the fact that it profited Judas nothing to have a place prepared, since he lost it by his own fault.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:8
verses.text: And we must interpret in the same way what our Lord says to the sons of Zebedee, one of whom wished to sit on His left hand, the other on His right:"My cup indeed ye shall drink: but to sit on my right hand, and on my left hand, is not mine to give, but it is for them for whom it hath been prepared of my Father".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:9
verses.text: It is not the Son's to give; how then is it the Father's to prepare? There are, He says, prepared in heaven, many different mansions, destined for many different virtues, and they will be awarded not to persons, but to persons' works.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:10
verses.text: In vain therefore do you ask of me what rests with yourselves, a reward which my Father has prepared for those whose virtues will entitle them to rise to such dignity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:11
verses.text: Again when He says: "I will come again, and will receive you unto myself: that where I am, there ye may be also," He is speaking especially to the apostles, concerning whom it is elsewhere written, "That as I and thou, Father, are one, so they also may be one in us," inasmuch as they have believed, have been perfected, and can say,"the Lord is my portion".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:12
verses.text: If, however, there are not many mansions, how is it taught in the Old Testament correspondingly with the New, that the chief priest has one rank, the priests another, the Levites another, the door-keepers another, the sacristans another? How is it that in thebook of Ezekiel, where a description is given of the future Church and of the heavenly Jerusalem, the priests who have sinned are degraded to the rank of sacristans and doorkeepers, and although they are in the temple of God, that is on the right hand, they are not among the rams, but among the poorest of the sheep? How again is it that in the river which flows from the temple, and replenishes the salt sea, and gives new life to everything, we read there are many kinds of fish? Why do we read that in the kingdom of heaven there are Archangels, Angels, Thrones, Dominions, Powers, Cherubim and Seraphim, and every name which is named, not only in this present world, but also that which is to come? A difference of name is meaningless where there is not a difference of rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:13
verses.text: An Archangel is of course an Archangel to other inferior angels, and Powers, and Dominions have other spheres over which they exercise authority.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:14
verses.text: This is what we find in heaven and in the administration of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 28:15
verses.text: You must not therefore smile and sneer at us, as is your wont, for making a graduated series of emperors, praefects and counts, tribunes and centurions, companies, and all the other steps in the service.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:2
verses.text: It is mere trifling to quote the passage:"Know ye not that your bodies are a temple of the Holy Ghost," for it is customary in Holy Scripture to speak of a single object as though it were many, and of many as though they were one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:3
verses.text: And Jovinianus himself should know that even in a temple there are many divisions—the outer and the inner courts, the vestibules, the holy place, and the Holy of Holies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:4
verses.text: There are also in a temple kitchens, pantries, oil-cellars, and cupboards for the vessels.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:5
verses.text: And so in the temple of our body there are different degrees of merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:6
verses.text: God does not dwell in all alike, nor does He impart Himself to all in the same degree.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:7
verses.text: A portion of the spirit of Moses was taken and given to the seventy elders.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:8
verses.text: I suppose there is a difference between the abundance of the river, and that of the rivulets.
