verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:9
verses.text: Elijah's spirit was given in double measure to Elisha, and thus double grace wrought greater miracles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:10
verses.text: Elijah while living restored a dead man to life; Elisha after death did the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:11
verses.text: Elijah invoked famine on the people; Elisha in a single day put the enemy's forces in the power of the city which they besieged.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:12
verses.text: No doubt the words, "Know ye not that your bodies are a temple of the Holy Ghost," refer to the whole assembly of the faithful, who, joined together, make up the one body of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:13
verses.text: But the question now is, who in the body is worthy to be the feet of Christ, and who the head? who is His eye, and who His hand?—a distinction indicated by thetwo women in the Gospel, the penitent and the holy woman, one of whom held His feet, the other His head.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:14
verses.text: Some authorities, however, think there was only one woman, and that she who began at His feet gradually advanced to His head.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:15
verses.text: Jovinianus further urges against us our Lord's words,"I pray not for these only, but also for those who shall believe on me through their word: that as I, Father, in thee and thou in me are one, so they all may be one in us," and reminds us that the whole Christian people is one in God, and, as His well-beloved sons, are"partakers of the divine nature".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:16
verses.text: We have already said, and the truth must now be inculcated more in detail, that we are not one in the Father and the Son according to nature, but according to grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:17
verses.text: For the essence of the human soul and the essence of God are not the same, as the Manichaeans constantly assert.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:18
verses.text: But, says our Lord:"Thou hast loved them as thou hast loved me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:19
verses.text: You see, then, that we are privileged to partake of His essence, not in the realm of nature, but of grace, and the reason why we are beloved of the Father is that He has loved the Son; and the members are loved, those namely of the body".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:20
verses.text: For as many as received Christ, to them gave He power to become sons of God, even to them that believe on His name: which were born not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:21
verses.text: The Word was made flesh that we might pass from the flesh into the Word.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:22
verses.text: The Word did not cease to be what He had been; nor did the human nature lose that which it was by birth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:23
verses.text: The glory was increased, the nature was not changed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:24
verses.text: Do you ask how we are made one body with Christ? Your creator shall be your instructor:"He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood abideth in me, and I in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:25
verses.text: As the living Father sent me, and I live because of the Father, so he that eateth me, he also shall live because of me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:26
verses.text: This is the bread which came down out of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:27
verses.text: But the Evangelist John, who had drunk in wisdom from the breast of Christ, agrees herewith, and says:"Hereby know we that we abide in him, and he in us, because he hath given us of his Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:28
verses.text: Whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God abideth in him, and he in God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:29
verses.text: If you believe in Christ, as the apostles believed, you shall be made one body with them in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 29:30
verses.text: But, if it is rash for you to claim for yourself a faith and works like theirs when you have not the same faith and works, you cannot have the same place.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:2
verses.text: You repeat the words bride, sister, mother, and affirm that all these are titles of the one Church and names applied to all believers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:3
verses.text: The fact goes against you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:4
verses.text: For if the Church admits but one rank, and has not many members in one body, what necessity is there for calling her bride, sister, mother? It must be that she is the bride of some, the sister of others, the mother of others.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:5
verses.text: All indeed stand on the right hand, but one stands as a bridegroom, another as a brother, a third as a son".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:6
verses.text: My little children" says the Apostle, "of whom I am again in travail until Christ be formed in you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:7
verses.text: Do you think that the children who are being born and the apostle who is in travail are of equal rank? And the folly of your contention that we love all the members alike, and do not prefer the eye to the finger, nor the hand to the ear, but that if one be lost all mourn, is proved by the lesson which the apostle teaches the Corinthians:"Some members are more honourable, others excite the sense of shame: and those parts to which shame attaches are clothed with more abundant honour; whereas our comely parts have no need of our care".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:8
verses.text: Do you think that the mouth and the belly, the eyes and the outlets of the body are to be classed together as of equal merit?"The lamp of thy body," he says, "is thine eye.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:9
verses.text: If thine eye be blinded, thy whole body is in darkness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:10
verses.text: If you cut off a finger, or the tip of the ear, there is indeed pain, but the loss is not so great, nor is the disfigurement attended by so much pain as it would be were you to take out the eyes, mutilate the nose, or saw through a bone.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:11
verses.text: Some members we can dispense with and yet live: without others life is an impossibility.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:12
verses.text: Some offences are light, some heavy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:13
verses.text: It is one thing to owe ten thousand talents, another to owe a farthing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:14
verses.text: We shall have to give account of the idle word no less than of adultery; but it is not the same thing to be put to the blush, and to be put upon the rack, to grow red in the face and to ensure lasting torment.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:15
verses.text: Do you think I am merely expressing my own views? Hear what the Apostle John says:"He who knows that his brother sinneth a sin not unto death, let him ask, and he shall give him life, even to him that sinneth not unto death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:16
verses.text: But he that hath sinned unto death, who shall pray for him?" You observe that if we entreat for smaller offences, we obtain pardon: if for greater ones, it is difficult to obtain our request: and that there is a great difference between sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:17
verses.text: And so with respect to the people of Israel who had sinned a sin unto death, it is said to Jeremiah:"Pray not thou for this people, neither entreat for them, and do not withstand me, for I will not hear thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:18
verses.text: Moreover, if it be true that we all alike enter the world and all alike leave it, and this is a precedent for the world to come, it follows that whether righteous or sinners we shall all be equally esteemed by God, because the conditions of our birth and death are now the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:19
verses.text: And if you contend that there are two Adams, the one of the earth, the other from heaven; and that they who were in the earthly Adam stand on the left hand, those who were in the heavenly are on the right hand, before we go further, let me ask you a question concerning two brothers: Was Esau in the earthly Adam, or in the heavenly? No one doubts that you will reply, he was in the earthly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:20
verses.text: In which was Jacob? Without hesitation you will say, in the heavenly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 30:21
verses.text: How then was he in the heavenly when Christ had not yet come in the flesh—Christ who is called the second Adam from heaven? You must either reckon all before the incarnation of Christ in the old Adam, and even the just in the man from the earth, and then they will be on the left among your goats; or, if it be impious to give Isaac the same place as Ishmael, Jacob as Esau, the saints as sinners, the last Adam will date from the time when Christ was born of a Virgin, and your argument from the two Adams will not benefit your sheep and goats, because we have proved that in the first Adam there were both sheep and goats, and that of those who were in one and the same man, some stood on the right hand of God, others on the left:"For from Adam even until Moses death reigned over all, even over them that had not sinned after the likeness of Adam's transgression".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:2
verses.text: As regards your attempt to show that railing and murder, the use of the expression raca and adultery, the idle word and godlessness, are rewarded with the same punishment, I have already given you my reply, and will now briefly repeat it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:3
verses.text: You must either deny that you are a sinner if you are not to be in danger of Gehenna: or, if you are a sinner you will be sent to hell for even a light offence:"The mouth that lieth," says one, "kills the soul".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:4
verses.text: I suspect that you, like other men, have occasionally told a lie:for all men are liars, that God alone may be true,and that He may be justified in His words, and may prevail when He judges.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:5
verses.text: It follows either that you will not be a man lest you be found a liar: or if you are a man and are consequently a liar, you will be punished with parricides and adulterers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:6
verses.text: For you admit no difference between sins, and the gratitude of those whom you raise from the mire and set on high will not equal the rage against you of those whom for the trifling offences of daily life you have thrust into utter darkness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:7
verses.text: And if it be so that in a persecution one is stifled, another beheaded, another flees, or the fourth dies within the walls of a prison, and one crown of victory awaits various kinds of struggle, the fact tells in our favour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:8
verses.text: For in martyrdom it is the will, which gives occasion to the death, that is crowned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:9
verses.text: My duty is to resist the frenzy of the heathen, and not deny the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:10
verses.text: It rests with them either to behead, or to burn, or to shut up in prison, or enforce various other penalties.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:11
verses.text: But if I escape, and die in solitude, there will not at my death be the same crown for me as for them, because the confession of Christ will not have been to me as to them the cause of death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:12
verses.text: As for your remark that absolutely no difference was made between the brother who had always been with his father, and him who was afterwards welcomed as a penitent, I am willing to add, if you like, that the one drachma which was lost and was found was put with the others, and that the one sheep which the good shepherd, leaving the ninety and nine, sought and brought back, made up the full tale of a hundred.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:13
verses.text: But it is one thing to be a penitent, and with tears sue for pardon, another to be always with the father.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:14
verses.text: And so both the shepherd and the father say by the mouth of Ezekiel to the sheep that was carried back, and to the son that was lost,"And I will establish my covenant with thee; and thou shalt know that I am the Lord: that thou mayest remember, and be confounded, and never open thy mouth ever more, because of thy shame, when I have forgiven thee all that thou hast done".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:15
verses.text: That penitents may have their due it is enough for them to feel shame instead of all other punishment.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:16
verses.text: Hence in another place it is said to them, "Then shall ye remember your evil ways, and all the crimes wherewith ye were defiled, and ye shall loathe yourselves in your own sight for all the wickedness that ye have done; and ye shall know that I am the Lord, when I shall have done you good for my name's sake, and not according to your evil ways, nor according to your evil doings".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:17
verses.text: The son, moreover, was reproved by his father for envying his brother's deliverance, and for being tormented by jealousy while the angels in heaven were rejoicing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:18
verses.text: The parallel, however, is not to be drawn between the merits of the two sons (one of whom was temperate, the other a prodigal) and those of the whole human race, but the characters depicted are either Jews and Christians, or saints and penitents.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 31:19
verses.text: In the lifetime of Bishop Damasus I dedicated to him a small treatise upon this parable.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:2
verses.text: And if a penny was given to all the labourers, those of the first, the third, the sixth, the ninth, and the eleventh hours, and they came first for the reward who were the last to work in the vineyard, even here the persons described do not belong to one time or one age, but from the beginning of the world to the end of it there are different calls and a special meaning attaches to each.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:3
verses.text: Abel and Seth were called at the first hour: Enoch and Noah at the third: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob at the sixth: Moses and the prophets at the ninth: at the eleventh the Gentiles, to whom the recompense was first given because they believed on the crucified Lord, and inasmuch as it was hard for them to believe they earned a great reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:4
verses.text: Many kings and prophets have desired to see the things that we see, and have not seen them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:5
verses.text: But the one penny does not represent one reward, but one life, and one deliverance from Gehenna.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:6
verses.text: And as by the favour of the sovereign those guilty of various crimes are released from prison, and each one, according to his toil and exertions, is in this or that condition of life, so too the penny, as it were by the favour of our Sovereign, is the discharge from prison of us all by baptism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 32:7
verses.text: Now our work is, according to our different virtues, to prepare for ourselves a different future.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:2
verses.text: So far I have replied to the separate portions of his argument; I shall now address myself to the general question.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:3
verses.text: Our Lord says to his disciples,"Whosoever would become great among you, let him be least of all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:4
verses.text: If we are all to be equal in heaven, in vain do we humble ourselves here that we may be greater there.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:5
verses.text: Of the two debtors who owed, one five hundred pence, the other fifty, he to whom most was forgiven loved most.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:6
verses.text: And so the Saviour says,"I say to you, her sins which are many are forgiven her, for she hath loved much.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:7
verses.text: But to whom little is forgiven, the same loveth little".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:8
verses.text: He who loves little, and has little forgiven, he will of course be of inferior rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:9
verses.text: The householder when he set out delivered to his servants his goods, to one five talents, to another two, to another one, to each according to his ability.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:10
verses.text: Just as in another Gospel it is written that a nobleman setting out for a far country to receive for himself a kingdom and return, called the servants, and gave them each a sum of money, with which one gained ten pounds, another five, and they, each according to his ability and the gain he had made, received ten or five cities.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:11
verses.text: But one who had received a talent, or a pound, buried it in the ground, or tied it up in a napkin, and kept it until his master's return.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:12
verses.text: Our first thought is that if, according to the modern Zeno, the righteous do not toil in hope of reward, but to avoid the loss of what they already have, he who buried his pound or talent that he might not lose it, did no wrong, and the caution of him who kept his money is worthy of more praise than the fruitless toil of those who wore themselves out and yet received no reward for their labour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:13
verses.text: Then observe that the very talent which was taken from the timid or negligent servant, was not given to him who had the smaller profit, but to him who had gained the most, that is, to him who had been placed over ten cities.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:14
verses.text: If difference of rank is not constituted by the difference in number, why did our Lord say, "He gave to everyone according to his ability"? If the gain of five talents and ten talents is the same, why were not ten cities given to him who gained the least, and five to him who gained the most? But that our Lord is not satisfied with what we have, but always desires more, He himself shows by saying, "Wherefore didst thou not give my money to the money-changers, that so when I came I might have received it with usury?" The Apostle Paul understood this, andforgetting those things which were behind, reached forward to those things which were in front, that is, he made daily progress, and did not keep the grace given to him carefully wrapped up in a napkin, but his spirit, like the capital of a keen man of business, was renewed from day to day, and if he were not always growing larger, he thought himself growing less.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:15
verses.text: Six cities of refuge are mentioned in the law, provided for fugitives who were involuntary homicides, and the cities themselves belonged to the priests.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:16
verses.text: I should like to ask whether you would put those fugitives among your goats, or among our sheep.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:17
verses.text: If they were goats, they would be slain like other homicides, and would not enter the cities of God's ministers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:18
verses.text: If you say they were sheep, they will not possibly be such sheep as can enjoy full liberty and feed without fear of wolves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:19
verses.text: And it will be plain to you that sheep indeed they are, but wandering sheep: that they are on the right hand, but do not stand there: they flee until the High Priest dies and descending into hell liberates their souls.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:20
verses.text: The Gibeonites met the children of Israel, and although other nations were slaughtered, they were keptfor hewers of wood and drawers of water.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:21
verses.text: And of such value were they in God's eyes, that the family of Saul was destroyed for the wrong done to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:22
verses.text: Where would you put them? Among the goats? But they were not slain, and they were avenged by the determination of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:23
verses.text: Among the sheep? But holy Scripture says they were not of the same merit as the Israelites.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:24
verses.text: You see then that they do indeed stand on the right hand, but are of a far inferior grade.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:25
verses.text: Jonathan came between David, the holy man, and Saul, the worst of kings, and we can neither place him among the kids because he was worthy of a prophet's love, nor amongst the rams lest we make him equal to David, and particularly when we know that he was slain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:26
verses.text: He will, therefore, be among the sheep, but low down.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:27
verses.text: And just as in the case of David and Jonathan, you will be bound to recognize differences between sheep and sheep".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:28
verses.text: That servant, which knew his lord's will, and made not ready, nor did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes; but he that knew not, and did things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with few stripes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:29
verses.text: And to whomsoever much is given, of him shall much be required: and to whom they commit much, of him will they ask the more".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 33:30
verses.text: Lo! more or less is committed to different servants, and according to the nature of the trust, as well as of the sin, is the number of stripes inflicted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:2
verses.text: The whole account of the land of Judah and of the tribes is typical of the church in heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:3
verses.text: Let us read Joshua the son of Nun, or the concluding portions of Ezekiel, and we shall see that the historical division of the land as related by the one finds a counterpart in the spiritual and heavenly promises of the other.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:4
verses.text: What is the meaning of the seven and eight steps in the description of the temple? or again, what significance attaches to the fact that in the Psalter, after being taught the mystic alphabet by theone hundred and eighteenth psalm we arrive by fifteen steps at the point where we can sing:"Behold, now bless the Lord, all ye servants of the Lord: ye who stand in the house of the Lord, in the courts of the house of our God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:5
verses.text: Why didtwo tribes and a half dwell on the other side of Jordan, a district abounding in cattle, while the remaining nine tribes and a half either drove out the old inhabitants from their possessions, or dwelt with them? Why did the tribe of Levireceive no portion in the land, but have the Lord for their portion? And how is it that of the priests and Levites, themselves, thehigh priest alone entered the Holy of Holies where were the cherubim and the mercy-seat? Why did the other priests wearlinen raiment only, and not have their clothing of wrought gold, blue, scarlet, purple, and fine cloth? The priests andLevites of the lower order took care of the oxen and wains: those of the higher order carried the ark of the Lord on their shoulders.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:6
verses.text: If you do away with the gradations of the tabernacle, the temple, the Church, if, to use a common military phrase, all upon the right hand are to be "up to the same standard," bishops are to no purpose, priests in vain, deacons useless.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 34:7
verses.text: Why do virgins persevere? widows toil? Why do married women practise continence? Let us all sin, and when once we have repented, we shall be on the same footing as the apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:2
verses.text: But now we have just sighted land: the foaming billows have been rolling mountain-high: our ship has been borne aloft, or has rushed headlong into the depths beneath: little by little the haven opens to the view of the weary and exhausted sailors.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:3
verses.text: We have discussed the married, widows, and virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:4
verses.text: We have preferred virginity to widowhood, widowhood to marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:5
verses.text: The passage of the apostle, in which he treats questions of this kind, has been expounded, and particular objections have been met.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:6
verses.text: We also took a survey of secular literature, and inquired what was thought of virgins, and what of those who had one husband; and by way of contrast we pointed out the cares which sometimes attend wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:7
verses.text: Then we passed to the second division, in which our opponent denies the possibility of sinning to those who have been baptized with complete faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:8
verses.text: And we showed that God alone is faultless, and every creature is at fault, not because all have sinned, but because all may sin, and those who stand have cause to fear when they see the fall of men like themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:9
verses.text: In the third place we came to fasting, and inasmuch as our opponent's argument fell under two heads, and he appealed either to philosophy, or to Holy Scripture, we also furnished a several reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:10
verses.text: In the fourth, that is the last section, the sheep and goats on the right hand and the left, the righteous and the wicked, were distributed into two classes, the intention being to show that there is no difference between one just man and another, or between one sinner and another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 35:11
verses.text: To prove the point Jovinianus had accumulated countless instances from Scripture which apparently favoured his view, and this contention we rebutted both by arguments and illustrations from Scripture, and pulverized Zeno's old opinion no less with common sense than with the words of inspiration.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:2
verses.text: I must in conclusion say a few words to our modern Epicurus wantoning in his gardens with his favourites of both sexes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:3
verses.text: On your side are the fat and the sleek in their festal attire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:4
verses.text: If I may mock like Socrates, add if you please, all swine and dogs, and, since you like flesh so well, vultures too, eagles, hawks, and owls.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:5
verses.text: We shall never be afraid of the host ofAristippus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:6
verses.text: If ever I see a fine fellow, or a man who is no stranger to the curling-irons, with his hair nicely done and his cheeks all aglow, he belongs to your herd, or rather grunts in concert with your pigs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:7
verses.text: To our flock belong the sad, the pale, the meanly clad, who, like strangers in this world, though their tongues are silent, yet speak by their dress and bearing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:8
verses.text: Woe is me," say they, "that my sojourning is prolonged! that I dwell among the tents of Kedar!" that is to say, in the darkness of this world, for the light shineth in the darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:9
verses.text: Boast not of having many disciples.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:10
verses.text: The Son of God taught in Judaea, and only twelve apostles followed Him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:11
verses.text: I have trodden the wine-press alone," He says, "and of the peoples there was no man with me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:12
verses.text: At the passion He was left alone, and even Peter's fidelity to Him wavered: on the other hand all the people applauded the doctrine of the Pharisees, saying, "Crucify him, crucify him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:13
verses.text: We have no king but Caesar," that is in effect, we follow vice, not virtue; Epicurus, not Christ; Jovinianus, not the Apostle Paul.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:14
verses.text: If many assent to your views, that only indicates voluptuousness; for they do not so much approve your utterances, as favour their own vices.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:15
verses.text: In our crowded thoroughfares a false prophet may be seen any day stick in hand belabouring the fools about him, and knocking out the teeth of those who offend him, and yet he never lacks constant followers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:16
verses.text: And do you regard it as a mark of great wisdom if you have a following of many pigs, whom you are feeding to make pork for hell? Since you published your views, and set the mark of your approval on baths in which the sexes bathe together, the impatience which once threw over burning lust the semblance of a robe of modesty has been laid bare and exposed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:17
verses.text: What was once hidden is now open to the gaze of all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:18
verses.text: You have revealed your disciples, such as they are, not made them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:19
verses.text: One result of your teaching is that sin is no longer even repented of.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:20
verses.text: Your virgins whom, with a depth of wisdom never found before in speech or writing, you have taught the apostle's maxim that it is better to marry than to burn, have turned secret adulterers into acknowledged husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 36:21
verses.text: It was not the apostle, the chosen vessel, who gave this advice; it was Virgil's widow:   "She calls it wedlock; thus she veils her fault".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:2
verses.text: About four hundred years have passed since the preaching of Christ flashed upon the world, and during that time in which His robe has been torn by countless heresies, almost the whole body of error has been derived from the Chaldaean, Syriac, and Greek languages.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:3
verses.text: Basilides, the master of licentiousness and the grossest sensuality, after the lapse of so many years, and like a second Euphorbus, was changed by transmigration into Jovinian, so that the Latin tongue might have a heresy of its own.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:4
verses.text: Was there no other province in the whole world to receive the gospel of pleasure, and into which the serpent might insinuate itself, except that which was founded by the teaching of Peter, upon the rock Christ? Idol temples had fallen before the standard of the Cross and the severity of the Gospel: now on the contrary lust and gluttony endeavour to overthrow the solid structure of the Cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:5
verses.text: And so God says by Isaiah, "O my people, they which bless you cause you to err, and trouble the paths of your feet".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:6
verses.text: Also by Jeremiah, "Flee out of the midst of Babylon, and save every man his life, and believe not the false prophets which say, Peace, peace, and there is no peace;" who are always repeating, "The temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:7
verses.text: "Thy prophets have seen for thee false and foolish things; they have not laid bare thine iniquity that they might call thee to repentance: who devour God's people like bread: they have not called upon God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:8
verses.text: Jeremiah announced the captivity and was stoned by the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:9
verses.text: Hananiah, the son of Azzur, broke the bars of wood for the present, but was preparing bars of iron for the future.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:10
verses.text: False prophets always promise pleasant things, and please for a time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:11
verses.text: Truth is bitter, and they who preach it are filled with bitterness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:12
verses.text: For with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth the Lord's passover is kept, and it is eaten with bitter herbs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:13
verses.text: Admirable are your utterances and worthy of the ears of the bride of Christ standing in the midst of her virgins, and widows, and celibates! (their very name isderived from the fact that they who abstain from intercourse are fit for heaven).

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:14
verses.text: This is what you say: "Fast seldom, marry often.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:15
verses.text: You cannot do the work of marriage unless you take mead, and flesh, and solid food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:16
verses.text: For lust strength is required.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:17
verses.text: Flesh is soon spent and enervated.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:18
verses.text: You need not be afraid of fornication.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:19
verses.text: He who has been once baptized into Christ cannot fall, for he has the consolation of marriage to slake his lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:20
verses.text: And if you do fall, repentance will restore you, and you who were hypocrites at baptism may have a firm faith in your repentance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:21
verses.text: Be not disturbed by the thought of a difference between the righteous and the penitent, and do not imagine that pardon even gives a lower place; rather believe that it takes away your crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:22
verses.text: For there is one reward: he who stands on the right hand shall enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:23
verses.text: Through counsels such as these your swine-herds are richer than our shepherds, and the he-goats draw after them many of the other sex:"They were as fed horses: they were mad after women": they no sooner see a woman than they neigh after her, and, shame to say! find scriptural authority for the consolation of their incontinence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:24
verses.text: But the very women, unhappy creatures! though they deserve no pity, who chant the words of their instructor (for what does God require of them but to become mothers?), have lost not only their chastity, but all sense of shame, and defend their licentious practices with an access of impudence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:25
verses.text: You have, moreover, in your army many subalterns, you have your guardsmen and your skirmishers at the outposts, the round-bellied, the well-dressed, the exquisites, and noisy orators, to defend you with tooth and nail.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:26
verses.text: The noble make way for you, the wealthy print kisses on your face.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:27
verses.text: For unless you had come, the drunkard and the glutton could not have entered paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:28
verses.text: All honor to your virtue, or rather to your vices! You have in your camp, even amazons with uncovered breasts, bare arms and knees, who challenge the men who come against them to a battle of lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:29
verses.text: Your household is a large one, and so in your aviaries not only turtle-doves, but hoopoes are fed, which may wing their flight over the whole field of rank debauchery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 37:30
verses.text: Pull me to pieces and scatter me to the winds: tax me with what offences you please: accuse me of luxurious and delicate living: you would like me better if I were guilty, for I should belong to your herd.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:2
verses.text: But I will now address myself to you, great Rome, who with the confession of Christ have blotted out the blasphemy written on your forehead.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:3
verses.text: Mighty city, mistress-city of the world, city of the Apostle's praises, shew the meaning of your name.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:4
verses.text: Rome is either strength in Greek, or height in Hebrew.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:5
verses.text: Lose not the excellence your name implies: let virtue lift you up on high, let not voluptuousness bring you low.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:6
verses.text: By repentance, as the history of Nineveh proves, you may escape the curse wherewith the Saviour threatened you in the Apocalypse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:7
verses.text: Beware of the name of Jovinianus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:8
verses.text: It is derived from that of an idol.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:9
verses.text: The Capitol is in ruins: the temples of Jove with their ceremonies have perished.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book II 38:10
verses.text: Why should his name and vices flourish now in the midst of you, when even in the time of Numa Pompilius, even under the sway of kings, your ancestors gave a heartier welcome to the self-restraint of Pythagoras than they did under the consuls to the debauchery of Epicurus?.
